{{distinguish|Great Seal of Canada}} {{Use Canadian English|date=December 2010}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{good article}} {{Infobox coat of arms |name = Arms of Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada
{{lang|fr|(Armoiries de Sa Majesté la Reine du chef du Canada)}} |image = Coat of arms of Canada.svg |image_width = 245px |lesser = |lesser_width = |lesser_caption = |image2 = |image2_width = |image2_caption = |image3 = |image3_width = |image3_caption = |armiger = [[Elizabeth II]] [[Monarchy of Canada|in Right of Canada]] |year_adopted = [[:File:Coat of arms of Canada (1923).jpg|19 November 1921]], revised 12 July 1994{{cite web | url=http://reg.gg.ca/heraldry/pub-reg/project-pic.asp?lang=e&ProjectID=461&ProjectImageID=1151 | title=Registration of the Armorial Bearings of Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada | publisher=Canadian Heraldic Authority | date=15 March 2005 | accessdate=16 March 2016 | author=Robert Douglas Watt}} |crest = Upon a Royal helmet, a lion passant guardant or imperially crowned proper and holding in the dexter paw a [[maple leaf]] Gules. |torse = Argent and gules, the mantling gules doubled argent. |shield = Tierced in fess, the first and second divisions containing the quarterly coat following, namely, 1st Gules three lions passant guardant in pale Or, 2nd, Or a lion rampant within a double tressure flory-counter-flory Gules, 3rd, Azure a harp Or stringed Argent, 4th, Azure three fleurs-de-lis Or, and the third division being Argent three maple leaves conjoined on one stem proper. |supporters = Dexter a lion Or holding a lance Argent, point Or, flying therefrom to the Dexter the Royal Union Flag, Sinister a unicorn Argent armed, crined and unguled Or, gorged with a coronet composed of crosses-patée and fleurs-de-lis a chain affixed thereto and reflexed Or, holding a like lance flying therefrom to the sinister a banner Azure charged with three fleurs-de-lis Or. |compartment = A wreath of [[Tudor Rose|roses]], thistles, [[shamrock]]s and lilies proper. |motto = {{lang-la|A Mari usque ad Mare|lit=from sea to sea}} |orders = The ribbon of the [[Order of Canada]] ({{lang-la|Desiderantes meliorem patriam|link=no|lit=they desire a better country}}) |other_elements = The whole ensigned by the Royal Crown proper. |earlier_versions = [[:File:Coat of arms of Canada (1921).jpg|Arms of Canada, revised 1957]] |use = }} The '''Arms of Canada''' ({{lang-fr|armoiries du Canada|links=no}}), also known as the '''Royal Coat of Arms of Canada''' ({{lang-fr|armoiries royales du Canada|links=no}}){{cite journal | url=http://publications.gc.ca/gazette/archives/p1/2007/2007-03-17/pdf/g1-14111.pdf| title=The Canadian Heraldic Authority – Approvals | author=Cook, Sheila-Marie | journal=Canada Gazette |date=March 2007 | volume=141 | issue=11 | pages=586| accessdate=24 February 2015}}{{Cite journal| last=Department of Canadian Heritage| author-link=Department of Canadian Heritage| title=Canada: Symbols of Canada| place=Ottawa| publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada|year=2016| url=http://canada.pch.gc.ca/eng/1444070816842| accessdate=3 September 2016}}{{cite hansard|title=Statements by Members {{ndash}} Royal Arms of Canada |url=http://www2.parl.gc.ca/HousePublications/Publication.aspx?Language=E&Mode=1&Parl=35&Ses=1&DocId=2332530#ROYALARMSOFCANADA |house=Commons |date=5 December 1995 |column_start=1410 |column_end=1415 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090310004425/http://www2.parl.gc.ca/HousePublications/Publication.aspx?Language=E&Mode=1&Parl=35&Ses=1&DocId=2332530 |archivedate=10 March 2009 }}{{cite web| url=http://www.mpcc-cppm.gc.ca/300/3000/2001/menu-eng.aspx| last=Military Police Complaints Commission| title=The Commission > Publications > Outlook With Vision: Annual Report 2001| publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada| accessdate=28 June 2009}}{{cite web| url=http://www.bankofcanada.ca/currencymuseum/eng/learning/coins_mapleleaf.php| last=Bank of Canada| title=Currency Museum > Learning Centre| publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada| accessdate=28 June 2009}} {{Dead link|date=April 2012|bot=H3llBot}}{{Cite journal| last=Reynolds| first=Ken| title=Pro Valore: Canada's Victoria Cross| place=Ottawa| publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada| page=40| edition=2| url=http://www.cmp-cpm.forces.gc.ca/dhh-dhp/pub/boo-bro/vc-cv/doc/vc-cv-eng.pdf| accessdate=31 July 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/site/feature-vedette/2008/05/16-eng.asp |last=Department of National Defence |authorlink=Department of National Defence (Canada) |title=Features > 2008 > Modern Canadian Victoria Cross unveiled at Rideau Hall |publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada |accessdate=4 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091202062236/http://www.forces.gc.ca/site/feature-vedette/2008/05/16-eng.asp |archivedate=2 December 2009 }}{{cite book| last=Bousfield| first=Arthur| author2=Toffoli, Gary| title=Fifty Years the Queen| publisher=Dundurn Press| year=2002| location=Toronto| page=35| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w8l5reK7NjoC&printsec=frontcover&q=| isbn=1-55002-360-8}}{{Cite book| last=Citizenship and Immigration Canada| author-link=Citizenship and Immigration Canada| title=Discover Canada| place=Ottawa| publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada| year=2009| pages=38, 61| url=http://www.cic.gc.ca/english/pdf/pub/discover.pdf| isbn=978-1-100-12739-2| accessdate=3 December 2009| ref=CITEREF_Citizenship_and_Immigration_Canada_2009| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091122160954/http://www.cic.gc.ca/english/pdf/pub/discover.pdf| archivedate=22 November 2009| deadurl=no}} or formally as the '''Arms of Her Majesty The Queen in Right of Canada''' ({{lang-fr|Armoiries de Sa Majesté la Reine du chef du Canada}}),{{cite web| url=http://archive.gg.ca/heraldry/pub-reg/project-pic.asp?lang=e&ProjectID=461&ProjectElementID=1555| title=The Public Register of Arms, Flags and Badges of Canada, Vol. IV, p. 457| publisher=The Canadian Heraldic Authority| accessdate=1 December 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/hgw-cgf/oversight-surveillance/communications/fip-pcim/index-eng.asp#toc3 | title=Federal Identity Program | publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada | accessdate=4 October 2016 | last=Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat | authorlink=Treasury Board Secretariat}}{{cite web| url=http://www.heraldry.ca/misc/coatArmsCanada.htm| title=The Coat of Arms of Canada – A Short History| publisher=Royal Heraldry Society of Canada| accessdate=28 June 2009| archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6547ogIP2?url=http://www.heraldry.ca/misc/coatArmsCanada.htm| archive-date=30 January 2012| dead-url=yes| df=dmy-all}}{{cite book| last=Tidridge| first=Nathan| title=Canada's Constitutional Monarchy: An Introduction to Our Form of Government| publisher=Dundurn Press| location=Toronto| page=71| year=2011| isbn=9781459700840| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JvGsvHsAtDgC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false}} is, since 1921, the official [[coat of arms]] of the [[Monarchy of Canada|Canadian monarch]] and thus also of [[Canada]].{{cite web | url=http://canadiancrown.gc.ca/eng/1396525887776 | title=Canadian Flags of the Royal Family | publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada | date=2 October 2014 | accessdate=9 December 2015 | author=Department of Canadian Heritage, Government of Canada | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160102234745/http://canadiancrown.gc.ca/eng/1396525887776 | archive-date=2 January 2016 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} It is closely modelled after the [[royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom]] with French and distinctive Canadian elements replacing or added to those derived from the British version. The [[maple leaves]] in the shield, [[blazon]]ed "proper", were originally drawn [[Vert (heraldry)|vert]] (green) but were redrawn [[gules]] (red) in 1957 and a circlet of the [[Order of Canada]] was added to the arms for limited use in 1987. The shield design forms the [[Royal standards of Canada#Sovereign's standard|monarch's royal standard]] and is also found on the [[Canadian Red Ensign]]. The [[Flag of the Governor General of Canada]], which formerly used the shield over the [[Union Flag]], now uses the [[crest (heraldry)|crest]] of the arms on a blue field. The arms are embossed on the cover of any [[Canadian nationality law|citizen]]'s [[Canadian passport]], in order to legally signify and symbolize that the bearer is travelling under the aid of the [[The Crown#Concept|Crown of Canada]]. ==History== [[Image:Blason proposé pour la province royale de Canada en 1663.svg|thumb|left|150px|Blason proposed for the [[New France|French Province of Canada]] in 1663.]] Prior to [[Canadian Confederation|Confederation]] in 1867, the [[Royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom|Royal Arms of the United Kingdom]] served in Canada as the symbol of royal authority.{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldry.ca/misc/coatArmsCanada.htm |title=Royal Heraldry Society of Canada: The Coat of Arms |publisher=RHSC |date= |accessdate=8 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201192257/http://www.heraldry.ca/misc/coatArmsCanada.htm |archivedate=1 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} Arms had not been granted to any of the colonies in [[British North America]], apart from 17th-century grants to [[Coat of arms of Nova Scotia|Nova Scotia]]{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/atc-ac/ns_e.cfm |title=Canadian Symbols Promotion – Nova Scotia |publisher=Canadian Heritage |date=21 May 2008 |accessdate=21 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080925114721/http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/atc-ac/ns_e.cfm|archivedate=25 September 2008}} and [[Coat of arms of Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]].{{cite web|url=http://www.assembly.nl.ca/Legislation/sr/statutes/c20.htm|title=RSNL1990 CHAPTER C-20 – COAT OF ARMS ACT|year=2006|publisher=Earl G. Tucker, Queen's Printer|accessdate=6 September 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://www.heritage.nf.ca/facts3.html |title=Heraldry and Flags: Newfoundland and Labrador Heritage |publisher=Memorial University of Newfoundland |accessdate=6 September 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080402042016/http://www.heritage.nf.ca/facts3.html |archivedate=2 April 2008 }} The year after Confederation, arms were granted by Royal Warrant on May 26, 1868 to [[Coat of arms of Ontario|Ontario]],{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/atc-ac/on_e.cfm |title=Ceremonial and Canadian Symbols Promotion – Ontario |publisher=Canadian Heritage |date=24 September 2007 |accessdate=21 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081022064914/http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/atc-ac/on_e.cfm |archivedate=22 October 2008 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} [[Coat of arms of Quebec|Quebec]],{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/atc-ac/qc_e.cfm |title=Ceremonial and Canadian Symbols Promotion – Quebec |publisher=Canadian Heritage |date=21 May 2008 |accessdate=21 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080910013110/http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/atc-ac/qc_e.cfm|archivedate=10 September 2008}} [[Coat of arms of Nova Scotia|Nova Scotia]]{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.ns.ca/legislature/HOUSE_OF_ASSEMBLY/Symbols/coat.htm |title=Nova Scotia/Nouvelle-Ecosse – Coat-of-Arms/Le blason |publisher=Government of Nova Scotia |date= |accessdate=31 October 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081210064609/http://www.gov.ns.ca/legislature/HOUSE_OF_ASSEMBLY/Symbols/coat.htm| archivedate= 10 December 2008| deadurl= no}} (that Nova Scotia had been granted arms was forgotten, and it took until 1929 for the historic arms granted in the 17th century to be reinstated) and [[Coat of arms of New Brunswick|New Brunswick]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/atc-ac/nb_e.cfm |title=Canadian Symbols Promotion – New Brunswick |publisher=Canadian Heritage |date=24 September 2007 |accessdate=21 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080606145242/http://www.pch.gc.ca/PROGS/CPSC-CCSP/atc-ac/nb_e.cfm |archivedate=6 June 2008 }} In the Royal Warrant of 1868, Queen Victoria authorized the four arms of the first provinces to be quartered for use on the Great Seal of Canada and while this was not done for the first Great Seal, it is through this reference it became the ''de facto'' arms for Canada until 1921.{{cite book |title=Use of Non-Traditional Evidence: A case study using heraldry to examine competing theories for Canada’s Confederation |author=Bruce M. Hicks |year= 2010 |publisher= British Journal of Canadian Studies 43 (1), pp.87-117| issn=0269-9222}} That is why it was in this form Canada was represented on the first [[Canadian Red Ensign|Red Ensign]] carried by Canadian troops at Vimy Ridge in 1917. A shield of arms first quartered and then, over time, as more provinces and territories joined Canada, marshalled with the arms of the new members of Confederation emerged through popular and even Canadian governmental usage. This eventually resulted in a shield with nine quarterings, an arrangement that had never been approved by the monarch. Nine quarterings on a shield was considered too complex for a national symbol and by 1915 a push had begun to design a new coat of arms for Canada.{{cite book|last=Fraser|first=Alistair B|title=The Flags of Canada|date=30 January 1998|chapter=Chapter I, Canada's National Symbols|url=http://fraser.cc/FlagsCan/index.html|chapterurl=http://fraser.cc/FlagsCan/Nation/NatSym.html|accessdate=1 October 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080915061016/http://fraser.cc/FlagsCan/index.html| archivedate=15 September 2008| deadurl=no}} A committee was formed in 1919 to pursue the issue, eventually agreeing that the elements of the new arms would reference the Royal Arms of England, Ireland, Scotland, and France, with maple leaves representing Canada, though there was at the time no consensus on how the leaves were to be used. The decision was settled by 1920, and the committee conferred with the [[College of Arms]] in London, only to face resistance to the use of the Royal Arms from the [[Garter King of Arms]]. After some manoeuvring, including the personal intervention of [[Winston Churchill]], the new arms of Canada were eventually formally requested by an [[Order in Council]] on 30 April 1921 and adopted on 21 November of the same year by proclamation of King [[George V]] as the Arms or Ensigns Armorial of the Dominion of Canada.{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/sc-cs/arm1_e.cfm |title=Ceremonial and Canadian Symbols Promotion – The arms of Canada |publisher=Canadian Heritage |date=23 June 2008 |accessdate=21 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080924075037/http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/sc-cs/arm1_e.cfm|archivedate=24 September 2008}}{{London Gazette|issue=32525|page=9242|date=22 November 1921}} The new layout closely reflected the arms of the United Kingdom{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/sc-cs/arm2_e.cfm |title=Ceremonial and Canadian Symbols Promotion – The arms of Canada (page 2)|publisher=Canadian Heritage |date=23 June 2008 |accessdate=21 November 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080924072609/http://www.pch.gc.ca/PROGS/CPSC-CCSP/sc-cs/arm2_e.cfm |archivedate=24 September 2008}} with the addition of maple leaves in the base and the reference to the French royal arms in the fourth quarter.{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/sc-cs/symboles-histoire-symbols-stories/symbole_canada_symbols-eng.pdf|title=Symbols of Canada|year=2008|publisher=Canadian Heritage|accessdate=20 November 2008|page=6}} The proclamation also established white and red as the [[national colours of Canada]]. In 1931, with the passage of the Statute of Westminster, Canada and other Dominions became fully sovereign from the United Kingdom. This had the effect of elevating the Canadian coat of arms, which had been granted as deputed arms for particular uses in a colony, to the status of the royal arms of the King in right of the country, for general purposes throughout the country. They thus replaced the British coat of arms, which had previously been arms of general purpose throughout the British Empire, in court rooms and on government buildings to represent the ruling monarch. This change can be seen in the Great Seal of Canada of George VI, where the royal arms of Canada replaced the British arms, and is even more evident in the Great Seal of Canada for [[Elizabeth II]], where the title has been redefined as ''Queen of Canada''.{{cite book|last=Swann|first=Conrad|title=Canada Symbols of Sovereignty: An investigation of the arms and seals borne from the earliest times to the present in connection with public authority in and over Canada. along with consideration of some connected flags|chapter=Chapter I, Arms of dominion and sovereignty and public authority|location=Toronto|publisher= University of Toronto Press}} These are the coat of arms of the Queen of Canada. By 1957, the arms were redrawn by [[Alan Beddoe]] so as to have red leaves and to change the royal crown from one of a Tudor design to one more resembling [[St. Edward's Crown]], as preferred by Queen Elizabeth II. To mark the 1982 [[patriation]] of the Canadian constitution, which finally ended the last vestiges of British authority over Canada, a [[McGill University]] student named Bruce Hicks proposed to [[Secretary of State (Canada)|Secretary of State]] [[Gerald Regan]] that the motto of the [[Order of Canada]] be placed around the shield in order to bring these royal arms into line with other royal arms, many of which have been displayed in Canada during French, Scottish, and English colonisation, where those countries' highest national order of honour appears around the shield of the arms (the British arms displayed the [[Order of the Garter]], the Scottish [[Royal coat of arms of Scotland|royal arms]] the [[Order of the Thistle]], and the royalist [[National Emblem of France|arms of the French Regime]] the [[Order of the Holy Spirit]] and [[Order of Saint Michael]]).{{cite book|last=Hicks|first=Bruce|title=The Campaign to Change the Royal Arms of Canada (Hogtown Heraldry 12:4)}} While unsuccessful in this first attempt, Hicks continued his campaign and was joined by a number of other amateur and professional heraldists. As a journalist in the parliamentary press gallery in Ottawa in the late 1980s and early 90s, Hicks strategically recast the change as something worth doing to commemorate the 25th Anniversary of the Order of Canada in 1992, an idea that was endorsed by the Advisory Committee on the Order of Canada.{{cite book|last=McCreery|first=Christopher|title=The Order of Canada: Its Origins, History and Development|isbn=0-8020-3940-5|location=Toronto|publisher=University of Toronto Press}} It took until 1994 for the Queen to approve the new design for general use, though the [[Canadian Heraldic Authority]] began to allow for its limited use beginning in 1987, where the arms were used to represent the Queen personally on letters patent granting new arms for distinguished Canadians. These letters patent carried the shield from the royal arms along with the annulus behind the shield bearing the motto of the [[Order of Canada]]—''Desiderantes meliorem patriam''. As soon as royal approval was forthcoming, the full achievement was redesigned for use by the federal government within the [[Federal Identity Program]]. The present design of the arms of Canada was drawn by [[Cathy Bursey-Sabourin]], Fraser Herald at the Canadian Heraldic Authority.{{cite book|last=Canadian Heritage|title=The Arms of Canada (Ottawa: Government of Canada)}} In June 2008, Member of Parliament [[Pat Martin]] introduced a [[Motion (democracy)|motion]] into the [[House of Commons of Canada]] calling on the government to amend the coat of arms to incorporate symbols representing Canada's [[First Nations]], [[Inuit]], and [[Métis people (Canada)|Métis]] peoples.{{Cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/coat-of-arms-ignores-aboriginal-people-mp-says-1.748913 |title=Coat of arms ignores aboriginal people, MP say |date=20 June 2008 |publisher=CBC |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080622224734/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2008/06/20/coat-arms.html |archive-date=22 June 2008 |dead-url=no |access-date=20 June 2008}} ===Armorial evolution=== Coat of arms of Canada (1868).svg|1868 1905 Canadian coat of arms postcard.jpg|1905 File:Coat of arms of Canada (1921).jpg|1921 Coat of arms of Canada (1923).jpg|1923 Coat of Arms of Canada (1957).png|1957 Coat of arms of Canada.svg|1994 ==Use== [[File:Coats of arms of Canada on Currie Hall Mackenzie Building Royal Military College of Canada.JPG|thumb|Arms of Canada on [[Currie Hall]], [[Royal Military College of Canada]]]] [[File:1914 Canadian $5 gold reverse.jpg|thumb|A 1914 Canadian $5 coin, minted 1912–1914, featuring the 1868 version of the arms]] The arms of Canada are the arms of the sovereign and signify national sovereignty and ownership.{{cite book | title=Ceremonial and Procedural Handbook of Canada | publisher=Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada | year=2010 | pages=106}} They are used as a mark of authority by various government agencies and representatives, including the [[Prime Minister of Canada|prime minister]]{{cite web|url=http://pm.gc.ca/|title=Prime Minister of Canada / Premier ministre du Canada|publisher=Office of the Prime Minister|accessdate=1 October 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080930004739/http://pm.gc.ca/| archivedate= 30 September 2008| deadurl= no}} and [[Cabinet of Canada|Cabinet]],{{cite web|url=http://pm.gc.ca/eng/cabinet.asp |title=Prime Minister of Canada: The Ministry |publisher=Office of the Prime Minister |accessdate=1 October 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081002085203/http://pm.gc.ca/eng/cabinet.asp |archivedate=2 October 2008 |deadurl=yes }} and most [[Court system of Canada#Symbols|courts]], including the [[Supreme Court of Canada|Supreme Court]],{{cite web|url=http://www.scc-csc.gc.ca/|title=Supreme Court of Canada – Welcome Page |date=4 September 2008|publisher=[[Supreme Court of Canada]]|accessdate=1 October 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081009092236/http://www.scc-csc.gc.ca/| archivedate= 9 October 2008| deadurl= no}} as well as the [[Canadian Armed Forces]] and [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]].{{cite book| title=Canadian Forces Dress Instructions| publisher=Canadian Armed Forces| author=Canadian Forces Department of History and Heritage| year=2010| location=Ottawa}}{{cite web|url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/site/about/Insignia/arma_e.asp |title=National Defence and the Canadian Forces |publisher=Forces.gc.ca |date=30 October 2008 |accessdate=8 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080702084606/http://www.forces.gc.ca/site/About/Insignia/arma_e.asp |archivedate=2 July 2008 }}{{cite web| url=http://www.rcmp-grc.gc.ca/unif/badge-insigne-eng.htm#ranknonofficers| title=RCMP Badges and Insignia| publisher=Her Majesty the Queen of Canada as represented by the Minister of Public Safety| date=7 April 2014| accessdate=7 March 2016| author=Royal Canadian Mounted Police}} It is also present on all pre-polymer denominations of [[Banknotes of the Canadian dollar|Canadian banknotes]] (in fact, the way the arms were printed on each bill is a security feature),{{cite web|url=http://www.bankofcanada.ca/en/banknotes/education/pdf/91-b-l(01-08)_booklet_en.pdf |title=Check to Protect |publisher=Bank of Canada / Banque du Canada |accessdate=1 October 2008 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} as well as the [[50 cent piece (Canadian coin)|50¢ coin]],{{cite web|url=http://www.mint.ca |title=Royal Canadian Mint – Monnaie Royale Canadienne |publisher=Mint.ca |date= |accessdate=21 November 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081204011602/http://www.mint.ca/| archivedate= 4 December 2008| deadurl= no}} and on the cover of [[Canadian passport]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.pptc.gc.ca/pptc/specifications.aspx?lang=eng|title=Passport Canada: Features of the Passport|publisher=Passport Canada|accessdate=1 October 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090308035327/http://www.pptc.gc.ca/pptc/specifications.aspx?lang=eng|archivedate=8 March 2009|df=dmy-all}} Since 1962, a [[Heraldic flag#Banner|banner]] of the arms, [[Defacement (flag)|defaced]] with a variant of the [[Royal Cypher|Queen's cypher]], has formed the [[Royal standards of Canada|sovereign's standard for Canada]], for use by the Queen in her capacity as monarch of Canada.{{cite book|last=Fraser|first=Alistair B|title=The Flags of Canada|date=30 January 1998|chapter=Chapter II, Canada's Head of State|url=http://fraser.cc/FlagsCan/Nation/StateHead.html|accessdate=1 October 2008| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080917025446/http://www.fraser.cc/FlagsCan/Nation/StateHead.html| archivedate=17 September 2008| deadurl= no}} Since, six additional standards for use by other members of the [[Monarchy of Canada#Canada's royal family and house|Canadian Royal Family]] have been created. In the Canadian Armed Forces and Royal Canadian Mounted Police, the most senior non-commissioned ranks wear the 1957 version of the coat of arms as a badge of rank, representing the fact that they have received the Queen's warrant (as opposed |to the Queen's commission for officers). The revised 1957 and 1994 Arms of Canada are both protected official government symbols used to represent the state under the Federal Identity Program. Permanent resident cards issued from 2015 feature a holographic representation of the 1957 version of the coat of arms.{{cite web|url=http://www.cic.gc.ca/english/department/media/multimedia/video/pr-card/pr-card.asp=eng|title=Permanent Resident Card|publisher=Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada|accessdate=12 July 2017}}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The full achievement of the coat of arms has been used by the Canadian government on occasion on a plain red flag, such as in 1967 for [[Canadian Centennial|the country's centennial celebrations]].{{cite web| url= http://flagspot.net/flags/ca_coa.html | title = Canadian Coat of Arms flag| author= Flags of the World|date=February 2004| accessdate=14 April 2007}} It is also used on a flag in its full achievement in military ceremonies, such as Canadian Armed Forces Tattoo performances.{{cite web| url= http://regimentalrogue.tripod.com/blog/index.blog?topic_id=1129460 | title = The Minute Book| author= The News and Eastern Townships Advocate|date=25 May 1967|accessdate=15 May 2015}} The personal [[Flag of the Governor General of Canada|flag of the Governor General]] has, since 1981, featured the crest of the royal arms of Canada on a blue background.{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/sc-cs/o7_e.cfm|title=Ceremonial and Canadian Symbols Promotion – Personal Flags and Standards|publisher=Minister of Public Works and Government Services|accessdate=4 September 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080621163539/http://www.pch.gc.ca/PROGS/CPSC-CCSP/sc-cs/o7_e.cfm |archivedate=21 June 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://archive.gg.ca/heraldry/emb/index_e.asp|title=Symbols of the Governor General|publisher=Rideau Hall|accessdate=4 September 2008}} In response to a new campaign by Bruce Hicks for the Canadian Parliament to have a distinct heraldic symbols along the lines of the [[portcullis]] (variations of which are used by the Commons and Lords in the British Parliament),{{cite book|last=Hicks|first=Bruce|title= A ‘Call to Arms’ for the Canadian Parliament" (Canadian Parliamentary Review 23:4)}} a proposal that was supported by [[Speaker of the House of Commons of Canada|Speakers of the House of Commons]] [[John Allen Fraser|John Fraser]] and [[Gilbert Parent]], a Commons committee was eventually struck following a motion by MP Derek Lee, before which Hicks and [[Robert Watt]], the first [[Chief Herald of Canada]], were called as the only two expert witnesses, though Senator [[Serge Joyal]] joined the committee ex-officio on behalf of the Senate. Commons' Speaker{{cite web|url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/information/about/people/House/Speaker/index_e.html|title=The Speaker – House of Commons Canada – Welcome|publisher=Parliament of Canada|accessdate=1 October 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080928141122/http://www.parl.gc.ca/information/about/people/House/Speaker/index_e.html| archivedate= 28 September 2008| deadurl= no}} [[Peter Milliken]] then asked the Canadian Heraldic Authority to authorize such a symbol and, on 15 February 2008, the Governor General authorized the House of Commons to begin using a badge of the shield of the royal arms superimposed on the [[ceremonial mace]] assigned to the House of Commons as a symbol of the royal authority under which it operates.{{cite web|url=http://archive.gg.ca/heraldry/pub-reg/project.asp?lang=e&ProjectID=1246|title=Public Register of Arms- House of Commons|publisher=[[Governor General of Canada]]|accessdate=7 October 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www2.parl.gc.ca/Sites/LOP/Education/CanSymbols/galleries/parliament/hoc_mace-e.asp |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120919124424/http://www2.parl.gc.ca/Sites/LOP/Education/CanSymbols/galleries/parliament/hoc_mace-e.asp |dead-url=yes |archive-date=19 September 2012 |title=Library of Parliament – Canadian symbols at Parliament |accessdate=23 August 2010 }} Following the Commons example, the [[Senate of Canada|Senate]] then requested and obtained on 15 April 2008 a similar badge for itself with the shield of the royal arms surmounted on the mace assigned to the Senate.{{cite web|url=http://archive.gg.ca/heraldry/pub-reg/project.asp?lang=e&ProjectID=1283|title=Public Register of Arms- Senate|publisher=[[Governor General of Canada]]|accessdate=7 October 2010}} ==Blazon== The [[Heraldry|heraldic]] [[blazon]] of Canada's coat of arms, as declared in the 1921 proclamation, is:
Tierced in fesse the first and second divisions containing the quarterly coat following, namely, 1st, [[gules]] three lions passant guardant in [[pale (heraldry)|pale]] [[Or (heraldry)|Or]], 2nd, Or a lion rampant within a double tressure flory-counter-flory gules, 3rd, [[Azure (heraldry)|azure]] a harp Or stringed [[argent]], 4th, azure, three fleurs-de-lis Or, and the third division argent three maple leaves conjoined on one stem proper. And upon a royal helmet mantled argent doubled gules the crest, that is to say, on a wreath of the colours argent and gules a lion passant guardant Or imperially crowned proper and holding in the dexter paw a maple leaf gules. And for supporters on the dexter a lion rampant Or holding a lance argent, point Or, flying therefrom to the dexter the [[Union Flag]], and on the sinister a unicorn argent armed crined and unguled Or, gorged with a coronet composed of crosses-patée and fleurs-de-lis a chain affixed thereto reflexed of the last, and holding a like lance flying therefrom to the sinister a banner azure charged with three fleurs-de-lis Or; the whole ensigned with the Imperial Crown proper and below the shield upon a wreath composed of roses, thistles, shamrocks and lillies a scroll azure inscribed with the motto A mari usque ad mare.
The circlet of the [[Order of Canada]] was added around the shield for limited use in 1987, and for general use in 1994. ==Symbolism== {| class="wikitable noresize" |- ! Element ! Description ! Image |- ! Crown | The coat of arms are surmounted by a rendition of [[St. Edward's Crown]], which has been used in the [[coronation]]s of Canada's monarchs. This element represents Canada's status as a [[constitutional monarchy]] headed by a sovereign king or queen. This style of crown is that preferred by Queen Elizabeth II, and was modernized in 1957 from the 1921 design, which used the Tudor crown.{{-}} | [[File:Canadian Crown.svg|center|130x130px]] |- ! Crest | The [[crest (heraldry)|crest]] is based on the Royal Crest of the United Kingdom but differenced by the addition of a maple leaf, and symbolizes the sovereignty of Canada.{{cite web|url=http://archive.gg.ca/heraldry/emb/index_e.asp|title=Symbols of the Governor General|publisher=Rideau Hall|accessdate=21 November 2008}} It appears on the [[Flag of the Governor General of Canada|flag of the Governor-General]], symbolizing that the Governor General is a representative of the Sovereign. The crest consists of a crowned gold lion standing on a twisted [[Torse|wreath]] of red and white silk and holding a maple leaf in its right paw.{{-}} | [[File:Canadian Crest.svg|center|130x130px]] |- ! Helm | The arms show a royal [[Helmet#Heraldry|helmet]], which is a barred helm of gold embossed with a maple leaf design looking outward, with [[mantling]] of white and red, stylized in the official version to look like maple leaves. {{-}} | [[File:Canadian Helm.svg|center|130x130px]] |- ! Escutcheon | The [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|escutcheon]] is divided into five sections. The first [[Division of the field|division]] at the viewer's top left contains the three golden [[Lion (heraldry)|lions]] that have been a symbol of England since at least the reign of [[Richard I of England|King Richard I]].{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldica.org/topics/britain/royalarm.htm |title=Royal Arms of Britain |publisher=Heraldica.org |date= |accessdate=21 November 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081206035142/http://www.heraldica.org/topics/britain/royalarm.htm| archivedate= 6 December 2008| deadurl= no}} The second quarter bears the red lion [[charge (heraldry)|rampant]] of [[Scotland]] in a double tressure border with [[fleur-de-lis|fleurs-de-lis]], used as a symbol of Scotland since at least the reign of [[William I of Scotland|William I]]. The third quarter shows the [[Coat of arms of Ireland|Irish harp]] of [[Tara, Ireland|Tara]]. The gold fleurs-de-lis of royal France, the first post-[[Middle Ages|medieval]] European emblem raised in Canada by [[Jacques Cartier]], during his landing at Gaspé,{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldry.ca/top_en/top_historyHer.htm|title=The History of Heraldry in Canada|publisher=Royal Heraldry Society of Canada|date=28 April 2004|accessdate=21 August 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306201754/http://www.heraldry.ca/top_en/top_historyHer.htm|archive-date=6 March 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} fill the fourth quarter. The fifth [[Charge (heraldry)|charge]], a sprig of red [[maple]] leaves at the bottom, is a distinctly Canadian symbol that became gradually identified with the country throughout the 19th century.{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/sc-cs/symboles-histoire-symbols-stories/symbole_canada_symbols-eng.pdf|title=Symbols of Canada|year=2008|publisher=Canadian Heritage|accessdate=20 November 2008|page=9}} They were first proposed as a symbol in 1834, were established in 1868 on the arms of [[Quebec]] and [[Ontario]] and officially became the national emblem in 1965, with the proclamation of the [[Flag of Canada]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/PROGS/CPSC-CCSP/sc-cs/df7_e.cfm |title=Ceremonial and Canadian Symbols Promotion – You were asking |publisher=Canadian Heritage |date=24 September 2007 |accessdate=21 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080924102524/http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/sc-cs/df7_e.cfm|archivedate=24 September 2008}} Initially, the leaves were depicted as coloured green on the coat of arms because it was thought to represent youth, as opposed to the red colour of dying leaves in autumn. However, they are blazoned as "proper", so could be shown as either red or green, and it is the blazon, rather than any depiction, which is regarded as authoritative. The leaves were later redrawn in official depictions in 1957 with the current colour to be in line with the official colours of Canada. They are further stylized in that natural maple leaves do not grow in sprigs of three. The shield forms the basis of the [[Queen's Personal Canadian Flag|royal standard of Canada]]. | [[File:Canadian Coat of Arms Shield.svg|center|130x130px]] |- ! Ribbon | The ribbon is marked ''desiderantes meliorem patriam'', meaning "desiring a better country," which is the motto of the [[Order of Canada]], taken from [[Epistle to the Hebrews|Hebrews]] 11:16. This component was added by the Queen in 1987 on the [[Advice (constitutional)|advice]] of her [[Brian Mulroney|Prime Minister]]. With the patriation of oversight of arms to Canada through the [[Canadian Heraldic Authority]] the following year,{{cite web|url=http://archive.gg.ca/heraldry/cha/index_e.asp|title=The Canadian Heraldic Authority|publisher=Canadian Heraldic Authority|date=27 September 2005 |origyear=updated 14 June 2006|accessdate=2 September 2008}} the constitution of the [[Order of Canada]] was amended to include entitlement by all recipients to encircle their own arms with the ribbon, if arms are granted to them.{{cite web|url=http://archive.gg.ca/honours/nat-ord/oc/oc-con_e.asp |title=The Constitution of the Order of Canada |publisher=[[Governor General of Canada]] |date=6 December 2005 |accessdate=21 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110530014527/http://archive.gg.ca/honours/nat-ord/oc/oc-con_e.asp |archivedate=30 May 2011 }} Since 1994 the arms used by government ministers and institutions have slowly changed to reflect the new version with the ribbon. | [[File:Order of Canada circlet (heraldry).svg|center|130x130px]] |- ! Motto | The [[motto]] of Canada is in Latin ''a mari usque ad mare'' (From sea to sea), a part of [[Psalms|Psalm]] 72:8.{{cite web|url=https://thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/a-mari-usque-ad-mare/ |title=A Mari usque ad Mare |last=Lamb |first=W. Kaye |work=The Canadian Encyclopedia |publisher=Historica Foundation of Canada |accessdate=21 November 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070817072335/http://thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=A1ARTA0000001 |archivedate=17 August 2007 |df=dmy }} This phrase was suggested by [[Joseph Pope (public servant)|Joseph Pope]], then-Under Secretary of State, when the Arms were redesigned in 1921. The motto was originally used in 1906 on the head of the mace of the [[Legislative Assembly of Saskatchewan]]. In March 2006, the premiers of Canada's [[Territories of Canada|three territories]] called for the amendment of the motto to better reflect the vast geographic nature of Canada's territory,{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/News/Ideas/article/271165 |title= Time to herald our northern coast?|date=28 October 2007 |author=Andrew Chung|accessdate=21 November 2008 | location=Toronto | work=The Star| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081013082850/http://www.thestar.com/News/Ideas/article/271165| archivedate= 13 October 2008| deadurl= no}} as Canada has coastlines on the [[Arctic Ocean|Arctic]], [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]], and [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] Oceans. Two suggestions for a new motto are ''A mari ad mare ad mare'' (from sea to sea to sea) and ''A mari usque ad maria'' (from the sea to the other seas).{{cite news |last=Deveau |first=Scott |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20060309.wmotto0309/BNStory/National/home |title=From sea to sea to sea |publisher=Theglobeandmail.com |date=3 September 2006 |accessdate=21 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6547u6u8q?url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/subscribe.jsp?art=815507 |archivedate=30 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news|author=CBC News |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2006/03/10/northern-motto060310.html |title='To sea' or not 'to sea': that is the question |publisher=Cbc.ca |date= 10 March 2006|accessdate=21 November 2008}} | [[File:Canadian Motto.svg|center|130x130px]] |- ! Supporters | [[Supporters|Supporting]] the shield on either side are the English lion and Scottish [[unicorn]], which are also the supporters of the [[Royal Coat of Arms of the United Kingdom|UK coat of arms]]. The English lion stands on the viewer's left and holds a gold-pointed silver lance flying the [[Union Flag]]. The Scottish unicorn has a gold horn, a gold mane, gold hooves, and around its neck a gold, chained [[coronet]] of crosses and fleurs-de-lis; it holds a lance flying the three gold fleurs-de-lis of royal France on a blue background. Unlike the British version, the lion is not crowned, nor is it facing the viewer. The broken chain on the unicorn symbolizes the unicorn's resistance to oppression. | [[File:CcoasupportersB.JPG|center|130x130px]] |- ! Compartment | The entire coat of arms rests on the [[Compartment (heraldry)|compartment]], which is made up of the floral emblems of the founding nations. The [[Tudor rose]] is the floral badge of England and Wales, combining the [[White Rose of York]] and the [[Red Rose of Lancaster]]. The [[thistle]] and [[shamrock]] are the symbols of Scotland and Ireland, respectively, while the [[fleur-de-lis]] has been the royal symbol of France since the 12th century.{{cite book|last=Lewis|first=Philippa|author2=Darley, Gillian|title=Dictionary of Ornament|publisher=Pantheon|year=1986|isbn=978-0394509310}} | [[File:Canadian Compartment.svg|center|130x130px]] |} ==Legal== As the Royal Arms are personal to the sovereign they cannot be used without consent.{{cite web | url=http://canadiancrown.gc.ca/eng/1396461395578 | title=Royal arms and insignia | publisher=Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada | date=1 June 2012 | accessdate=20 January 2014 | author=Government of Canada}} The coat of arms "as designed in 1921 and revised in 1957...(and) in 1994" are "protected under the ''Trade-marks Act'' and the ''Copyright Act'' and cannot be used or reproduced without authorization".{{cite web | url=http://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/fip-pcim/spec/T105-eng.asp | title=Legal Protection (Canada) | publisher=Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada | date=10 May 2012 | accessdate=23 April 2015 | author=Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat (Government of Canada)}} Further, "Marks and designs similar to the official symbols are pursued as a copyright or trade-mark infringement". The ''Trade-marks Act'' further states that "No person shall adopt in connection with a business, as a trade-mark or otherwise, any mark consisting of, or so nearly resembling as to be likely to be mistaken for... the arms, crest or flag adopted and used at any time by Canada".{{Cite canlaw|short title= Trade-marks Act|abbr= R.S.C.|year= 1985|chapter= T-13|section= 9|subsection= 1(e)|link= http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/T-13/page-3.html#docCont|linkloc= Department of Justice Canada|wikilink= Canadian trade-mark law}} In addition, under Crown copyright, "permission is always required when the work is being revised, adapted, or translated regardless if the purpose of the reproduction is for personal or public non-commercial distribution".{{cite web|url=http://www.publications.gc.ca/site/eng/ccl/aboutCrownCopyright.html |title=About Crown Copyright |publisher=Government of Canada Publications |date=5 March 2013 |accessdate=1 July 2013 |author=Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130604180718/http://publications.gc.ca/site/eng/ccl/aboutCrownCopyright.html |archivedate=4 June 2013 }} ==See also== {{Wikipedia books|Canada}} *[[Flag of Canada]] *[[List of Canadian provincial and territorial symbols]] *[[Great Seal of Canada]] *[[National symbols of Canada]] *[[Gallery of country coats of arms]] *[[Royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom]] *[[English claims to the French throne]] *[[New France]] *[[British North America]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Coats of arms of Canada}} *[http://canada.pch.gc.ca/eng/1444070816842#a2 The Arms of Canada (Canadian Heritage)] {{more footnotes|date=November 2013}} [[File:AthenaSömek1.jpg|thumb|Athena Relief of Sömek]] The '''Athena relief of Sömek''' is a Greco-Roman [[rock relief]], located some two kilometres north of the village of [[Sömek, Silifke|Sömek]] in [[Silifke]] district of [[Mersin province]] in Turkey, near the valley of the [[Limonlu Çayı|Limonlu]] river, the ancient Lamos. In antiquity, the river formed the border between "Rugged [[Cilicia]]" (Kilikia Tracheia) in the west and "Flat Cilicia" (Kilikia Pedias) in the east.
== Description == [[File:AthenaSömek3.jpg|thumb|Right pilaster with symbols and candelabrum]] The relief is carved in the living rock at a height of some 1.5 metres above the ground. It has a total height of 1.3 metres. In a niche finished with a conch-shaped top, the image of a woman is found, who can be identified as the goddess [[Athena]] thanks to the inscription, among other things. On both sides the niche is formed from blocky [[pilaster]]s, topped by wide capitals. The goddess is dressed in a [[peplos]], the ''apoptygma'', or upper layer, of which is bound by a girdle at the waist. On the lower part, the robe is tightly fitted to her body, such that her calves are clearly visible underneath. The material covers up her ankles and feet, at the sides of it wrinkle lines go from it to the ground. [[File:AthenaSömek2.jpg|thumb|left|Inscription]] The right arm of the figure is raised and holds a lance. Her left, pointing down to the ground, holds a shield on edge. The lance rests on a column, which connects directly to the left pilaster. A snake winds around the lance and column, with its lower end reaching along the ground to Athena's feet. The head and mane of a bridled horse can be seen above the shield and left arm of the goddess and its hindquarters disappear behind her right arm. On the right pilaster there is a star, a crescent moon and a thunderbolt to be seen. Between the moon and the thunderbolt, traces of a servered head can be made out. Similar traces are found to the left of the left pilaster, which is itself undecorated. To the right of the righthand limit of the image, a symbol has been engraved, consisting of a stand with two crescent moons on top and a ball with star. Serra Durugönül, who investigated the Cilician rock reliefs in the 1980s, thought this was a candelabrum, that is a cult object, to be interpreted as a simplified depiction of a [[Judaism|Jewish]] [[Menorah (Temple)|menorah]].
Between the lance on the left and the female figure an inscription of 13 lines is engaved in a narrow field. In it the goddess is referred to as ΑΘΗΝΑ ΚΡΙΣΟΑ (Athena Krisoa);. The [[epithet]] ΚΡΙΣΟΑ, derived from a place name, indicates a local variant of the divinity, but the place connected with the epithet cannot yet be located. It would certainly have been found in the north of Rough Cilica, however. The same epithet shows up in another inscription in the area and in both inscriptions Athena is also referred to as ΟΡΕΙΑ (Oreia, meaning "mountaindweller")<ref>On the cult of Athena Oreia, which is attested only in Cilicia, see Emanuela Borgia: ''Il culto di Athena Oreia in Cilicia.'' In: Michel Mazoyer (Hrsg.): ''La campagne antique: espace sauvage, terre domestiquée.'' Paris 2003, {{ISBN|2-7475-4977-1}}, S. 73–89.</ref>
== Interpretation and Dating == The depiction of the goddess corresponds to the [[Athena Parthenos]] type, modelled on [[Phidias]]' free-standing statue in the [[Parthenon]] on the [[Athens|Athenian]] [[Acropolis of Athens|Acropolis]]. Numerous imitations of this statue were made even in ancient times - another one has also been found in Cilicia. Similarities with Phidias' original include, above all, the clothing, the shield and the column standing on the left. In the original statue, this was a support of the right hand, in wehich Athena held [[Nike (goddess)|Nike]]. Even though this no longer has a function, since this statue is carved in relief and doesn't hold Nike, the artist was unwilling to omit this characteristic attribute.
Particularly on account of the type of clam-shell vault of the relief, Durugönül identified two possible dates for the creation of the relief. The first would be the time of the Emperors [[Claudius]] and [[Nero]] in the 1st century, the second would be the period after [[Hadrian]] in the 2nd and 3rd centuries AD. She inclines to the second, dating the relief to the 2nd century, on the basis of comparison with other rock reliefs of [[Asia Minor]], among which is that of a moongod at [[Sumatar Harabesi]] in [[Osrhoene]], which an inscription dates after 165.
== Bibliography == * Serra Durugönül: ''Athena Krisoa Oreia.'' In: ''Epigraphica Anatolica.'' 10, 1987, S. 115–116. * Serra Durugönül: ''Die Felsreliefs im Rauhen Kilikien''. (BAR International Series, 511). BAR, Oxford 1989, {{Listed Invalid ISBN|0-86954-652-7}}, S. 50–51, 128–137. * Serra Durugönül, Ahmet Mörel: ''Evidence of Judaism in Rough Cilicia and its Associations with Paganism.'' In: ''Istanbuler Mitteilungen.'' 62, 2012, S. 303–322.
