{{italic title}} [[File:Den tyske ordens skjold.svg|thumb|right|Emblazonment of the Order of Teutonic Knights.]] [[File:Teuton flag.svg|thumb|right|Emblazonment of the Order's Grand Master.]] The '''''Banderia Prutenorum''''' is a manuscript of 48 [[parchment]] sheets, 18.6 by 29.3 cm (7.3 by 11.5 inches), composed by [[Jan Długosz]] and illuminated by Stanisław Durink, listing 56 ''vexillae'', or [[banner]]s, of the Order of the [[Teutonic Knights]]. The title means ''Blazons of the Prussians''.According to ''Webster's Third New International Dictionary'', [[Gothic language|Gothic]] has ''bandwa'', "sign", from which Germanic [http://www.bartleby.com/61/roots/IE36.html *bandwa-], "sign", is reconstructed. From this comes [[Late Latin]] ''banderia'', which Webster's hypothesizes has a Latin formative suffix, -arium. It could as well be from a Germanic plural. Banner comes from it, but the earlier meaning was not the cloth but the signs. [[Blazon]] has a similar origin from a different but synonymous root, [http://www.bartleby.com/61/roots/IE50.html *bhel-], at least in the sense of "sign." In [[Middle English]] it has the connotation of shield, but this also is a secondary development. Heraldry originates with the Roman army, who put their unit signs on shields but not flags. ''Banderia'' therefore imitate the shield blazons in cloth. Royal and national "blazons" go beyond the original intent, which was only unit identification, and are therefore a later development. ''Prutenorum'' is the [[genitive]] plural of ''Pruteni'', [[Old Prussians|Prussians]]. In Polish the name is ''Chorągwie Pruskie''. ''Chorągwie'' can mean ''banner'', ''standard'', or ''regiment''. The heraldic term [[blazon]] in English is probably the exact meaning. ==Historical circumstances of the Banderia== The work describes the [[gonfalon]]s, or battle flags,The original Germanic [http://www.bartleby.com/61/96/G0189600.html *gundfanon-] meant "battle-flag". According to ''Webster's Third New International Dictionary'', this descends through [[Old High German]] ''gunfano'', "[[war flag]]" to [[Middle French]] and modern English gonfanon, a very rare word, and through [[Italian language|Italian]] ''gonfalone'' to English [[gonfalon]], synonymous with gonfanon. The modern terms have ceased to mean battle flags except when historians use them to refer to battle flags. collected from the field after the [[Battle of Grunwald]] in 1410 AD. This battle was a major confrontation between the Teutonic Order and the allied forces of [[Poles]] and [[Lithuanians]], whom the Order was trying to conquer. At that time, the Order had succeeded in subjecting or eliminating the western Balts, including the Prussians; however, the Teutonic Knights were decisively defeated by the joint forces of the [[Crown of the Kingdom of Poland]] and the Grand Duchy of Lithuania under the command of the Polish King [[Władysław II Jagiełło]]. At the end of the battle, the major officers of the Order lay dead on the field beside the standards under which they had fought. Some units escaped with their standards. The Banderia does not describe all the order's flags. The flags were collected and stored at [[Wawel Cathedral]] in [[Cracow]]. They are known to have been there in 1603, after which they disappeared. They have been recreated, starting in the 1900. In October 2009, as part of the preparations for the battle's anniversairy, Polish scholars and artists in Kraków have finished reconstructing all known standards.{{pl icon}} Magdalena Piwnicka, ''Znaki świetnego zwycięstwa'', Focus - Historia, Nr 7-8. 2010 ==Composition== It was probably the Polish historian, [[Jan Długosz]], who commissioned the painter, Stanisław Durink of [[Cracow]], to illustrate the flags in 1448. Długosz then wrote the [[Latin]] descriptions. The work thus has the format of a catalog, with an [[Illuminated manuscript|illumination]] and Latin entry for each flag. The flag is decorated with a heraldic blazon identifying the ''comturia'', or district, from which the soldiers of that unit came. The blazon might appear in any circumstances, such as in a [[coat of arms]] or on a shield, or in any conspicuous place. Its function was that of identification. The rules of heraldry were undoubtedly followed. The title raises a few questions of language and society. In it a Polish scholar and historian is calling the conquerors of the Prussians by that very name, even though at the beginning of their conquest they found the name odious to them. Old Prussian speakers still lived in substantial numbers in east Prussia. As they were not excluded from military service, some must have fought for the order, and yet they are not distinguished from the Germans in any way. ''Banderium'' is in origin neither Latin nor Polish, but comes from the Germanic. The place names also are in their Germanic forms rather than their Polish ones. Why Długosz, a Polish historian, chose to use the Germanicized Prussian Latin is not clear. ==Location of the manuscript== By some miracle, the manuscript survived World War II, even though it was given to [[Malbork]] castle by the Nazis for political purposes. After the war it showed up at a London auction house and was brought to its current location in the library of [[Jagiellonian University]]. ==Notes on the work== In the scholarly Latin of manuscript terminology, a ''[[recto]]'' page is "on the right side". The ''[[verso]]'' or "turned side" (the other side of the page) is therefore a left-hand page. This terminology has nothing to do with Długosz. Durink states the width (''latitudo'') and length (''longitudo'') of each flag in units he calls ''ulne'' (classical ''ulnae''). These must be [[cubit]]s rather than [[ell]]s; i.e., one ''ulna'' is 18 inches by today's standard ell. The flags are generally longer than they are wide. Page 1 recto bears the following introduction:
Pro libraria universitatis studii Cracouiensis datum per dominum Johannem Dlugosch. Descriptio Prutenicae cladis seu crucigerorum sub Jagellone per Joannem Dlugosz canonicum Cracoviensem. Banderia Prutenorum anno domini millesimo quadringentesimo decimo in festo Divisionis Apostolorum erecta contra Polonie regem Wladislaum Jagyelno et per eundem regem prostrata et Cracouiam adducta ac in ecclesia catedrali suspensa, que, ut sequitur, in hune modum fuerunt depicta.
A translation directly from the Latin is:
Given to the library of the university of study of Cracow by the master John Długosz. Description of the Prussian ruin or (the ruin) of the cross-bearers through Jagiello by John Dlugosz, canon of Cracow. The blazons of the Prussians in the year of the Lord 1410 in the holiday of the Divisio Apostolorum (Dispersal of the Apostles), which were erected against the king of Poland, Wladislaw Jagiello, and were cast down by the same king and brought to Cracow and hung in the church cathedral, were depicted in this manner, as follows.
The description to which Długosz refers is contained in the Latin notes with the flags. ==Comturiae mentioned in the work== [[Chełmno|Culm]], [[Pomesania]], [[Graudenz]], [[Balga]], [[Kowalewo Pomorskie|Schonsze]], [[Starogard Gdański|Stargard]], [[Sambia]], [[Tuchola|Tuchel]], [[Stuhm]], [[Nessau]], [[Westphalia]], [[Rogasen]], [[Elbing]], [[Pokrzywno, West Pomeranian Voivodeship|Engelsburg]], [[Brodnica|Strasburg]], [[Chełm, Warmian-Masurian Voivodeship|Chełm]], [[Brettchen]] and [[Neumark]], [[Braunsberg]]. ==Notes of this article== ==External links== {{commons category|Banderia Prutenorum}} {{commons category|Battle of Grunwald}} {{wikisourcelang|la}} *[http://www.laborunion.lt/memorandum/ru/modules/banderia/primus.htm Facsimile of Banderia Prutenorum, pages 1 recto through 11 recto.] *[http://www.laborunion.lt/memorandum/ru/modules/banderia/secundus.htm Facsimile of Banderia Prutenorum, pages 10 verso through 20 verso.] *[http://www.laborunion.lt/memorandum/ru/modules/banderia/tertius.htm Facsimile of Banderia Prutenorum, pages 20 verso through 30 verso.] *[http://www.laborunion.lt/memorandum/ru/modules/banderia/quartus.htm Facsimile of Banderia Prutenorum, pages 30 verso through 40 verso.] *[http://www.laborunion.lt/memorandum/ru/modules/banderia/quintus.htm Facsimile of Banderia Prutenorum, pages 40 verso through 48 verso.] *[http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/de_to_bp.html#ban Flags in the 'Banderia Prutenorum' Manuscript.] ''Flags of the World'' site. [[Category:Flag literature]] [[Category:15th century in Poland]] [[Category:German art]] [[Category:Jagiellonian University]] [[Category:15th-century illuminated manuscripts]] [[Category:Lithuanian chronicles]] [[Category:Teutonic Order]] [[Category:Polish manuscripts]] [[Category:15th-century Latin books]]

revision.comment: Removing the tag that was mistakenly added
revision.text:
The '''Birds Mosaic''' is a mosaic floor that was discovered in [[Caesarea]], [[Israel]].
==Discovery== [[File:Caesarea-Maritima-2-234.jpg|200px|thumb|right|General view of the mosaic. In the middle are cisterns.]] The mosaic was discovered in 1950 during a military exercise, and after five years was covered in sand to prevent deterioration. Archaeologist [[Shmuel Yeivin]] was the first to publish about it, and described it as a church due to the apse located in the east of the building. Since no pillars were found, he proposed that the church was without a roof. But in 1985 archaeologist [[Ronny Reich]] concluded that the site was the central part of a villa, rather than a church.
In 2004, the [[Israel Antiquities Authority]] removed the 70 cm thick dirt layer covering the mosaic, restored and strengthened it, and prepared it for visitors. The site was opened to the public in October 2005. Entrance to the site is free, and it is possible to walk on the mosaic.
==The site==
The mosaic floor belongs to a [[Byzantine]] palace that was built in the end of the 6th century or beginning of the 7th century, and which lay outside the walls of [[Caesarea Maritima|ancient Caesarea]]. The floor covered the central courtyard of the palace, which was led to by a portico on the west side. Surrounding it was a colonnade, rooms, and additional courtyards with mosaic floors. The built area of the palace was about 1500 square meters, and the entire settlement covered about 3 [[dunam]]s. It belonged to a wealthy Christian family, but no indications of its identity have been found. The building had an additional story which also had mosaic floors, parts of which collapsed when the palace was destroyed by fire, apparently during the [[Muslim conquest of the Levant|Arab conquest]] in 640. The wooden beams of the second floor were burned, and parts of its mosaic were found on the floor of the first story. ===The mosaic=== The mosaic takes up an area of 16 by 14.5 meters. It includes a frame decorated with fruit trees bearing large and beautiful fruit. Between the trees are large mammals in states of movement. The mammals include lions, leopards, bears, ibex, dogs, elephants, gazelle, oxen, wild boar, horse, and goat.
The center of the mosaic (surrounded by the frame) consists of 120 round medallions populated by large colorful birds, which give the mosaic its name. The medallions form 12 rows, with different kinds of birds in each row - [[peacocks]], [[storks]], [[pelicans]], [[herons]], [[pheasants]], grey-headed [[swamphen]], [[duck]], [[flamingo]], [[guineafowl]], [[ostrich]], [[rock partridge]] - all of them facing to the left. The sequence of birds is such that the same species is repeated along a diagonal in the medallion array.
Under the mosaic is a plastered cistern, to which drained rainwater from the entire complex. In the northwest corner of the site was a reservoir which received its water from a well. The complex was too high to receive water from Caesarea's aqueduct, so it needed an independent water supply.
===Table=== Another, unique, finding at the site was a table cover in the shape of the letter D, tiled with squares and triangles. The table was made with the "glass-gold" method - two layers of glass with a gold layer between it, and figures of crosses and flowers in the gold layer. When the palace was burned, the table overturned and was burned, while the cover was preserved on the floor. This cover was removed from the site for preservation.
==See also==
* [[Birds Mosaic (Jerusalem)]]
==External sources==
* R. Reich, A Figurative Mosaic from Caesarea, in: R. Reich, Some Byzantine remains, 'Atiqot (English Series) 17 (1986), pp. 205-213 * [http://www.archaeology.org.il/news44.html Gold Glass Table from Caesarea]
{{coord|32.5058|N|34.9033|E|source:wikidata|display=title}}
[[Category:Archaeological sites in Israel]] [[Category:Byzantine art]] [[Category:Caesarea (Israel)]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Defunct organizations based in the United States]]; added [[Category:Defunct organizations based in California]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
The '''Black Arts Council''' (BAC) was an organization founded in 1968 to advocate for African-American artists and support their community. Founded by [[Cecil Fergerson]] and Claude Booker (black art preparators who worked at the [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]], or LACMA), the organization comprised African-American artists, staff members, and other city residents who aimed to promote African-American art in Los Angeles. When the Black Arts Council was founded in 1968, every LACMA board member was white.<ref name=cooks>[https://books.google.com/books?id=sxHCWUnRGyQC&pg=PA87#v=onepage&q&f=false Cooks].</ref>
The organization grew to over 1,000 members in two years.<ref name=Holmes>{{cite news|last1=Holmes|first1=Emory|title=A Pit Bull in the World of Fine Art|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1999/feb/14/magazine/tm-7907|accessdate=14 December 2014|work=Los Angeles Times|date=1999-02-14}}</ref> It not only pressured LACMA to organize exhibitions for African-American artists, but also did extensive work supporting artists outside the museum.<ref name=Whos>{{cite web|title=Two Centuries of Black American Art at LACMA: Who's Who|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|url=http://www.lacma.org/whos-who|website=LACMA|publisher=LACMA|accessdate=14 December 2014}}</ref> The BAC organized student field trips to art exhibits, gave lectures at schools, and curated art exhibitions at various community locations and events.<ref name="Whos" />
The BAC's advocacy produced results in the form of two LACMA exhibitions: ''Three Graphic Artists: Charles White, [[David Hammons]], and Timothy Washington'' in 1971, and ''Panorama'' in 1972, featuring [[Noah Purifoy]], [[John Outterbridge]], and [[Betye Saar]].<ref name=Sirmans>{{cite web|last1=Sirmans|first1=Franklin|title=Remembering Cecil Fergerson (1931–2013)|url=http://unframed.lacma.org/2013/09/23/remembering-cecil-fergerson-1931-2013|website=LACMA Unframed|accessdate=14 December 2014}}</ref> These exhibits paved the path for LACMA's 1976 exhibition ''[[Two Centuries of Black American Art]]'', which traveled to the [[High Museum of Art]] in Atlanta, the [[Dallas Museum of Art|Dallas Museum of Fine Arts]], and the [[Brooklyn Museum]].<ref name="Sirmans" />
The BAC ceased activities in 1974 following Booker's death.<ref name="Whos" />
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:African-American arts organizations]] [[Category:Defunct organizations based in California]] [[Category:Arts organizations based in California]] [[Category:Organizations based in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1968]] [[Category:Arts organizations disestablished in the 20th century]] [[Category:Organizations disestablished in 1974]] [[Category:1968 establishments in California]] [[Category:1974 disestablishments in California]]

revision.comment: Rescued 3 archive links; reformat 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
{{Use Irish English|date=October 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{double image|right|Brian Cowen nude on toilet caricature.jpg|220|Painting of Brian Cowen holding underpants.jpg|200|Left: A painting hung in the [[National Gallery of Ireland]]
Right: A painting hung in the [[Royal Hibernian Academy]]}} Two [[oil painting]]s depicting the then-[[Taoiseach]] of Ireland [[Brian Cowen]] in the [[Nudity|nude]] were briefly displayed in [[Dublin]] art galleries in March 2009. The response of the media, politicians and the [[Garda Síochána]] (Irish police force) led to a sustained controversy referred to by some as '''Portraitgate'''.{{cite news|first=Miriam|last=Lord|authorlink=Miriam Lord|title=No losing sight of the big picture as Portraitgate rumbles on|work=[[The Irish Times]]|page=10|date=26 March 2009|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2009/0326/1224243452282.html|accessdate=3 April 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150302225829/http://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/oireachtas/no-losing-sight-of-the-big-picture-as-portraitgate-rumbles-on-1.730498|archivedate=2 March 2015}}{{cite news|first=Lise|last=Hand|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/portraitgate-just-who-called-who--is-finally-laid-bare-1693308.html|title=Portraitgate: just who called who is finally laid bare|newspaper=[[Irish Independent]]|page=18|date=1 April 2009|accessdate=3 April 2009}}{{cite news|first=Colin|last=Coyle|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/ireland/article5993135.ece|title=RTÉ's 'Portrait-gate' apology reopens self-censorship debate|newspaper=[[The Times]]|location=London|date=29 March 2009|accessdate=1 April 2009}} ==Portraits== The artist, initially unidentified, was eventually revealed to be Conor Casby, a school teacher in his thirties from Claremorris, [[County Mayo]]. The first portrait was surreptitiously hung in the [[National Gallery of Ireland]] on 7 March 2009. Casby is said to have entered the National Gallery carrying a shoulder bag, and located a free space for his portrait and its caption among other portraits of prominent Irish people such as [[Michael Collins (Irish leader)|Michael Collins]], [[W. B. Yeats]], and [[Bono]]. Casby then left the building unnoticed by security. It was reported as having read:
Brian Cowen, Politician 1960–2008. This portrait, acquired uncommissioned by the National Gallery, celebrates one of the finest politicians produced by Ireland since the foundation of the state. Following a spell at the helm of the Department of Finance during a period of unprecedented prosperity, Brian Cowen inherited the office of Taoiseach in 2008. Balancing a public image that ranges from fantastically intelligent analytical thinker to Big Ignorant Fucker from Offaly, the Taoiseach proves to be a challenging subject to represent.
The National Gallery called gardaí after it discovered the unauthorised painting. It has claimed that it had been hanging in public view for no more than twenty minutes before it was removed,{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/7964096.stm|title=Cowen artist 'could be charged'|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=25 March 2009|accessdate=27 March 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150302230238/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/7964096.stm|archivedate=2 March 2015}} contradicting the ''[[Sunday Tribune]]'''s claim that it hung for over an hour. The following day, 8 March, Casby hung a second painting of Cowen in the [[Royal Hibernian Academy]] (RHA). A woman attempted to buy the RHA portrait before it was removed.{{cite news|first=Ken |last=Foxe |url=http://www.tribune.ie/article/2009/mar/29/a-stunt-a-story-a-nut-and-a-hammer/ |title=A stunt, a story, a nut and a hammer |newspaper=[[Sunday Tribune]] |date=29 March 2009 |accessdate=29 March 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090331022003/http://www.tribune.ie/article/2009/mar/29/a-stunt-a-story-a-nut-and-a-hammer/ |archivedate=31 March 2009 |df= }} Both paintings{{cite web|url=http://blather.net/zeitgeist/archives/2009/03/brian_cowen_the_naked_taoiseac.html |title=Paintings on Google |publisher=Blather.net|date=24 March 2009|accessdate=27 June 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130520045245/http://blather.net/zeitgeist/archives/2009/03/brian_cowen_the_naked_taoiseac.html|archivedate=20 May 2013}}[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2009/0325/1224243368658.html Cowen nude portraits][http://noordinaryfool.com/2009/03/25/cowensunderpants/ The Emperor Has No Clothes] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091003033511/http://noordinaryfool.com/2009/03/25/cowensunderpants/ |date=3 October 2009 }} depict Cowen from the waist up, wearing only his glasses. In the RHA painting, he is holding a pair of blue and white underpants in his left hand. In the other, he is clutching a [[toilet paper|toilet roll]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/7960997.stm|title=Naked taoiseach paintings removed|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=24 March 2009|accessdate=27 March 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150302230406/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/7960997.stm|archivedate=2 March 2015}} ==Media reports== ''Sunday Tribune'' reporter Ken Foxe was contacted by a source at the National Gallery on 9 March and was the first to break the story of Cowen's portraits. Subsequently, "Topsy Campbell" (a pseudonym for Casby) sent [[camera phone]] photographs of the paintings on display. The incidents were first reported in the ''Tribune'' of 22 March.{{cite news|first=Ken|last=Foxe|url=http://www.tribune.ie/news/home-news/article/2009/mar/22/cowen-hung-out-to-dry-in-national-gallery-hijack/#image_1|title=Cowen hung out to dry in National Gallery hijack|newspaper=[[Sunday Tribune]]|date=22 March 2009|accessdate=1 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327191317/http://www.tribune.ie/news/home-news/article/2009/mar/22/cowen-hung-out-to-dry-in-national-gallery-hijack/#image_1|archivedate=27 March 2009|df=dmy-all}} ===RTÉ=== On 23 March, [[state broadcaster]] [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]] ran a report on the hangings at the end of the ''[[RTÉ News: Nine O'Clock|Nine O'Clock News]]''. The report by Tadhg Enright displayed the paintings, obtained an appraisal (of zero) from an art expert, and mentioned that Cowen was "not thought to have posed for the anonymous artist".{{cite news|first=Ronan|last=McGreevy|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2009/0326/1224243451815.html|title=Cowen not consulted before complaint to RTÉ|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|date=26 March 2009|accessdate=1 April 2009}} The report was not used on subsequent newscasts. On 24 March, the Nine O'Clock News included an apology "for any personal offence caused to Mr Cowen or his family or for any disrespect shown to the office of Taoiseach by [the prior] broadcast."{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/0325/breaking38.htm|title=Gardaí visit radio station in Cowen painting inquiry|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|date=25 March 2009|accessdate=28 March 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150302230609/http://www.irishtimes.com/news/garda%C3%AD-visit-radio-station-in-cowen-painting-inquiry-1.838054|archivedate=2 March 2015}} The original item was removed from the online archives at [[RTÉ.ie]], and the apology added. ===Today FM=== On 24 March, ''[[The Ray D'Arcy Show]]'' on commercial radio station [[Today FM]], covered the story. Producer [[Will Hanafin]] revealed that a friend of the artist had e-mailed photographs of a similarly styled painting to him in January, a caricature of the Taoiseach urinating in a full frontal nude pose. This painting has not been displayed publicly. A Garda detective visited the station requesting the emails. The Garda was said to have been "sheepish and apologetic" about the visit but indicated that he had received an order from "on high" to initiate an investigation. Hanafin refused to comply with the Garda request and, being told that a [[search warrant]] would be sought, labelled the entire affair as "crazy".{{cite web|url=http://www.examiner.ie/ireland/idqlqleysn/|title=Today FM producer brands reaction 'crazy'|newspaper=[[Irish Examiner]]|date=26 March 2009|accessdate=28 March 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150302224032/http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/idqlqleysn/|archivedate=2 March 2015}} ===Abroad=== The incident was covered by foreign newspapers, including ''[[The Times]]'' of London.{{cite news|first=David|last=Sharrock|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article5971027.ece|title=Brian Cowen is exposed to ridicule by art gallery guerrilla|newspaper=[[The Times]]|location=London|date=25 March 2009|accessdate=27 March 2009}} It was also covered in [[Canada]]. ===Online=== Blogs and [[social network service]]s such as Twitter were reported to be popular outlets for members of the general public to express their dissatisfaction at the attempted censorship and apology of RTÉ. A YouTube video of the original RTÉ news report had received more than three thousand views within twenty-four hours. The affair was nicknamed "Picturegate"{{cite web|url=http://www.siliconrepublic.com/news/article/12591/digital-life/picturegate-has-web-in-uproar|title=Irish internet in uproar over Picturegate censorship|work=Silicon Republic|date=26 March 2009|accessdate=26 March 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150302230815/http://www.siliconrepublic.com/news/article/12591/digital-life/picturegate-has-web-in-uproar|archivedate=2 March 2015}} and "Cowengate"{{cite web|url=http://www.cearta.ie/2009/03/cowengate-and-freedom-of-expression/|title=Cowengate and Freedom of Expression|work=cearta.ie|date=26 March 2009|accessdate=26 March 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150302230929/http://www.cearta.ie/2009/03/cowengate-and-freedom-of-expression/|archivedate=2 March 2015}} in online discussions. ==Garda investigation== The Garda investigation was said to have taken six hours. The possible crimes were offending [[decency]], [[Hate speech#Ireland|incitement to hatred]], and [[criminal damage]] for nailing the painting to the wall (though it has also been reported that paintings were hung without the use of nails){{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/arts/artdesign/story/2009/03/27/cowen-nudes.html?ref=rss|title=Artist behind naughty nudes of Irish PM emerges|work=CBC News|date=27 March 2009|accessdate=27 March 2009}} Investigators telephoned Casby and he entered Pearse Street Garda Station where he was interviewed for two hours, admitted to having hung the two paintings and was subsequently released.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0325/cowenb.html|title=Teacher questioned over Cowen paintings|publisher=[[RTÉ News]]|date=25 March 2009|accessdate=27 March 2009}} He gave gardaí five more portraits of other politicians, including [[Michael McDowell (politician)|Michael McDowell]]. A file was prepared for the [[Director of public prosecutions#Ireland|director of public prosecutions]], but it is expected that no charges will be brought. Casby expressed his desire to "draw an end" to the matter by auctioning the paintings for charity. ==Political reaction== The incidents attracted comment from politicians. The RTÉ News report was criticised as being in bad taste by [[Fianna Fáil]] [[Seanad Éireann|Senators]] [[Maria Corrigan]] and [[Mary O'Rourke]] and [[Teachta Dála|TDs]] [[M. J. Nolan]] and [[Michael Kennedy (Dublin politician)|Michael Kennedy]]. [[Fine Gael]] TD [[Michael W. D'Arcy]] called it the "most distasteful report I have seen on RTÉ in years". Kennedy urged consideration for the feelings of Cowen's wife and children, and called on [[Director-General of RTÉ]] [[Cathal Goan]] to resign, but did not advocate charging the artist. Some suggested the government had put pressure on RTÉ to withdraw the report and apologise, or on Today FM to co-operate with the Garda. The station received several complaints that the report was in bad taste, including one from the government press secretary, Eoghan Ó Neachtain, who claimed he was acting on his own initiative. [[Fine Gael]]'s [[Enda Kenny]]{{cite news|first=Michael|last=O'Regan|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2009/0327/1224243552769.html|title=Ceann Comhairle exasperated as Kenny fails to see the bigger picture|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|date=27 March 2009|accessdate=27 March 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150302231103/http://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/oireachtas/ceann-comhairle-exasperated-as-kenny-fails-to-see-the-bigger-picture-1.731374|archivedate=2 March 2015}} and [[Charles Flanagan]] called it a restriction on [[Freedom of speech|freedom of expression]].{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0326/cowenb.html|title=Opposition slams Govt over portrait pressure|publisher=[[RTÉ News]]|date=26 March 2009|accessdate=28 March 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150302231227/http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0326/115596-cowenb/|archivedate=2 March 2015}} [[Liz McManus]] of the [[Labour Party (Ireland)|Labour Party]] criticised RTÉ for "bow[ing] to political pressure". RTÉ claimed the decision to withdraw the report was taken by RTÉ executives, and that Ó Neachtain's complaint was received after the late-night ''[[RTÉ News on Two|News on Two]]'' had already been broadcast without the report. Some criticised the Garda investigation as a waste of resources. Fine Gael's [[Frances Fitzgerald (Irish politician)|Frances FitzGerald]] said it was "over the top"; [[Rónán Mullen]] defended it as appropriate. Labour's [[Joan Burton]] said "While I sympathise with the Taoiseach and his family, the public has noticed that it took gardaí six months to [[Anglo Irish Bank hidden loans controversy|go into the Anglo Irish Bank]]."{{cite news|url=http://www.tribune.ie/news/home-news/article/2009/mar/29/it-took-gardai-six-months-to-go-into-anglo-irish-r/ |title='It took Gardaí six months to go into Anglo Irish': reaction to cowengate |date=29 March 2009 |newspaper=[[Sunday Tribune]] |accessdate=1 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402180945/http://www.tribune.ie/news/home-news/article/2009/mar/29/it-took-gardai-six-months-to-go-into-anglo-irish-r/ |archivedate= 2 April 2009 |df= }} ==Legacy== The incidents are referred to in the 2009 episode of ''[[Reeling in the Years]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/tv/reelingintheyears/2009.html|title=The 2000s: 2009|work=Reeling in the Years}} In 2011, it was reported that both paintings were on display in Sean Mac D's pub in Dublin.{{cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/naked-brian-cowen-pictures-make-a-comeback-80608-Feb2011/|title=Naked Brian Cowen pictures make a comeback|publisher=TheJournal.ie|date=9 June 2013 |accessdate=27 June 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150302230102/http://www.thejournal.ie/naked-brian-cowen-pictures-make-a-comeback-80608-Feb2011/|archivedate=2 March 2015}} ==See also== * [[List of places where social nudity is practised]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * The two paintings ([[JPEG]]s from the ''Sunday Tribune'' article): ** [https://web.archive.org/web/20110221163306/http://media.tribune.ie/site_media/photologue/photos/2009/Mar/21/cache/Brian_Cowen_NAtional_Gall00_display.jpg National Gallery painting] ** [https://web.archive.org/web/20110221163301/http://media.tribune.ie/site_media/photologue/photos/2009/Mar/21/cache/Brian_Cowen_RHA006542_display.jpg RHA painting] * [[RTÉ.ie]]'s withdrawal of the portraits: [http://img21.imageshack.us/img21/9738/cowenballs2.png Altered captions] [http://img291.imageshack.us/img291/9844/cowenc.png Removal] * RTÉ.ie's [http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0323/cowennude.html report] which fuelled the controversy [http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0323/115462-cowennude/(archive link)]{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} * RTÉ's [https://web.archive.org/web/20090402153221/http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0323/cowennude_av.html?2514083%2Cnull%2C230 television apology] to the [[Taoiseach]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090329060918/http://www.tv3.ie/shows.php?request=nightlynewswithvincentbrowne&tv3_preview=&video=7089 Video] of [[Vincent Browne]]'s discussion on [[TV3 (Ireland)|TV3]] – 25 March 2009 {{Today FM}} [[Category:2009 controversies]] [[Category:2009 in Irish politics]] [[Category:2009 in Irish television]] [[Category:2009 in radio]] [[Category:2009 paintings]] [[Category:Brian Cowen|Nude]] [[Category:Caricature]] [[Category:Censorship in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Clothing-free events]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Taoisigh]] [[Category:Culture jamming]] [[Category:Nude art]] [[Category:Nudity and protest]] [[Category:Political satire]] [[Category:Political scandals in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:RTÉ controversies]] [[Category:The Ray D'Arcy Show]] [[Category:Portraits of politicians]]

{{EngvarB|date=December 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} The '''British National Opera Company''' presented opera in English in London and on tour in the British provinces between 1922 and 1929. It was founded in December 1921 by singers and instrumentalists from [[Thomas Beecham|Sir Thomas Beecham]]'s [[Beecham opera company]] (1915–1920), which was disbanded when financial problems over buying [[Thomas_Beecham#The_Bedford_Estate|The Bedford Estate]] forced Beecham to withdraw from the music scene for a short period. The new venture was financed by the issue of 40,000 preference shares at £1 each.<ref>''The Times'', 13 July 1921, p. 20</ref> Among the musicians who met at the inaugural meeting of the new enterprise at the [[Queen's Hall]] were [[Alexander Mackenzie (composer)|Sir Alexander Mackenzie]], [[Charles Villiers Stanford|Sir Charles Stanford]], [[Harry Plunket Greene]], [[Aylmer Buesst]] and [[William Henry Hadow|Sir Henry Hadow]]. The new company bought the entire assets of the Beecham company, comprising the scenery, costumes, scores, instruments and performing rights for 48 operas.<ref>''The Times'', 27 September 1921, p. 12</ref>
[[Image:Nellie Melba 1.jpg|right|150px|thumbnail|[[Nellie Melba]], who appeared with the company at Covent Garden]]The company's first performance was ''[[Aida]]'' at [[Bradford]] in February 1922, and received excellent notices.<ref>''The Times'', 7 February 1922, p. 8 and ''The Manchester Guardian'', 10 February 1922, p. 4</ref> For much of its existence the company toured in the provinces, but also had short seasons at [[Royal Opera House|Covent Garden]] (1922–1924) and then at [[Her Majesty's Theatre|His Majesty's Theatre]].<ref name=ency>[http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1O76-BritishNationalOperaCmpny.html BNOC on encyclopedia.com]</ref> For the 1923 Covent Garden season [[Nellie Melba|Dame Nellie Melba]] emerged from retirement to sing with the company. She gave her services free of charge, to support the company. She did not, however, feel equal to relearning her old roles in English translation, and she sang in Italian while the rest of the company sang in the vernacular.<ref>''The Times'', 4 January 1923, p. 10</ref>
The British National Opera Company was a pioneer of broadcast opera, with excerpts from ''[[The Magic Flute]]'' broadcast live from the [[Royal Opera House]] by the [[BBC|British Broadcasting Company]] in January 1923, less than a year after the foundation of both the BBC and the opera company.<ref>See ''[[The Times]]'', 9 January 1923, p. 8 and ''[[The Manchester Guardian]]'', 10 January 1923, p. 10. However, [[Harold Rosenthal]] in ''The New Grove Dictionary of Opera'' states that the BNOC gave "the first broadcast in Europe of a complete opera" from "the company's matinée performance of [[Hänsel und Gretel (opera)| Hänsel und Gretel]] at Covent Garden on 6 January 1923", but this conflicts not only with the ''Times'' and ''Guardian'' reports, but with the BBC's schedules: daily broadcasts did not begin until 5.00 p.m, too late for a relay of a matinée.</ref>
The company's first artistic director was [[Percy Pitt]], who had been music director with the Grand Opera Syndicate and who later worked as Director of Music for the [[BBC]]. His successor in 1924 was [[baritone]] [[Frederic Austin]], who in 1920 arranged the music for a revival of ''[[The Beggar's Opera]]'' at the [[Lyric Theatre (Hammersmith)]].<ref name=divine>{{Cite web |url=http://www.divine-art.com/AS/BNOC.htm# |title=BNOC on Divineart.com |access-date=3 October 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091118081729/http://www.divine-art.com/AS/BNOC.htm# |archive-date=18 November 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The Company had a wide repertory, which included works by [[Richard Wagner|Wagner]], [[Claude Debussy|Debussy]], [[Italian opera]] and several English works, including [[Ralph Vaughan Williams|Vaughan Williams]]'s ''[[Hugh the Drover]]'' and [[Gustav Holst]]'s ''[[The Perfect Fool]]'' and ''[[At the Boar's Head]]''.<ref name=ency/> The ''New Grove Dictionary of Opera'' singled out the company's staging of the ''[[Der Ring des Nibelungen|Ring]]'', ''[[Tristan und Isolde]]'', ''[[Parsifal]]'' and "a notable production in English of ''[[Pelléas and Mélisande]]'' with [[Maggie Teyte]]."<ref name=grove/>
British National Opera Company employed most of the leading British and British-based singers and conductors of that time, including conductors [[John Barbirolli]], [[Adrian Boult]], Aylmer Buesst, [[Hamilton Harty]], [[Gervase Hughes]] and [[Malcolm Sargent]], and singers [[Agnes Nicholls]], [[Florence Austral]], [[Joseph Hislop]], [[Edward Johnson (tenor)|Edward Johnson]], [[Dinh Gilly]], [[Harold Williams (baritone)|Harold Williams]], [[Norman Allin]], [[Robert Radford]], [[Dora Labbette]], [[Walter Widdop]], [[Frank Mullings]], [[Herbert Heyner]] and [[Heddle Nash]], among others.<ref name=divine/> In 1924, Beecham joined the company at His Majesty's for ''[[Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg]]''.<ref>''The Times'', 19 July 1924, p. 9</ref>
The company was short of money throughout its existence, and the resumption of international opera seasons at Covent Garden deprived the BNOC of its lucrative London seasons which had in the first years subsidised its provincial tours.<ref>''The Manchester Guardian'', 2 July 1929, p. 10</ref> The company ceased to exist in 1929 following a tax demand for £17,000 which forced it to go into voluntary liquidation.<ref name=divine/> Its last performances were ''[[Cavalleria rusticana]]'' and ''[[Pagliacci]]'' at the [[Golders Green Hippodrome]] in London, on 16 April 1929, in a season in which the conductors included Beecham, Barbirolli and [[Eugène Goossens, fils|Eugène Goossens]]. The company effectively re-formed as the [[Covent Garden English Opera Company]] in September 1929, with Barbirolli as its musical director, and continued under that name until 1938.<ref name=grove>Rosenthal, Harold, [http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/04014?q=%22first+broadcast%22+of+an+opera&search=quick&pos=14&_start=1#firsthit "British National Opera Company"], ''New Grove Dictionary of Opera''. Retrieved 10 October 2009 (subscription required)</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091118081729/http://www.divine-art.com/AS/BNOC.htm BNOC on Divineart.com] *[http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1O76-BritishNationalOperaCmpny.html BNOC on The Concise Oxford Dictionary of Music] *[http://www.havergalbrian.org/theoperas1.htm The operas of Havergal Brian]
