revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=December 2010}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2010}} [[File:Gilbert & Sullivan Opera Company.jpg|thumb|300px|right|National Gilbert & Sullivan Opera Company poster]] The '''National Gilbert & Sullivan Opera Company''' (formerly the '''Gilbert & Sullivan Opera Company''') is an English professional repertory company that performs [[Gilbert and Sullivan]]'s [[Savoy opera]]s. Founded in 1995 to perform at the [[International Gilbert and Sullivan Festival]], the company generally stages three or four productions each summer, giving up to 16 performances in [[Harrogate]], North Yorkshire, and also touring.
The company performs full-scale productions of the Gilbert and Sullivan works, with orchestra, using period settings and costumes. Since 2010, in addition to its performances at the festival, the company has generally performed one or more of its productions in an additional venue either before or after the festival. Since 2014, it has toured some of its productions to multiple British cities in repertory, giving up to 42 performances on tour.
==Background== The [[D'Oyly Carte Opera Company]] performed [[Gilbert and Sullivan]]'s [[Savoy Opera]]s continuously, year-round, for over a century, closing in 1982.<ref>Bradley, pp. 49–50; Joseph, p. 358. Between 1988 and 2003, a seasonal company used the name D'Oyly Carte. See Bradley, pp. 54–68</ref><ref>Skow, John. [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,921136,00.html 1982 "Music: Final Curtain for D'Oyly Carte"]. ''Time'' magazine, 8 March 1982, accessed 7 July 2010</ref> Until the Gilbert and Sullivan copyrights expired in 1961, no other professional theatre or opera companies were allowed to present the Savoy Operas in Britain, although professional companies performed the operas in North America, Australia and elsewhere, and numerous amateur Gilbert and Sullivan companies performed around the world. After 1961 other professional groups began to perform the operas in Britain.<ref>Bradley, chapters four and six</ref><ref name=Hewett>Hewett, Ivan. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/opera/5931987/The-magic-of-Gilbert-and-Sullivan.html "The Magic of Gilbert and Sullivan"]. ''The Telegraph'', 2 August 2009, accessed 14 April 2010.</ref>
In 1994, the [[International Gilbert and Sullivan Festival]] was founded by Ian and his son Neil Smith partly to fill the gap left by the closure of D'Oyly Carte, and it has been held every August since then in England.<ref name=Telegraph>Lee, Bernard. [http://www.sheffieldtelegraph.co.uk/classical/Gilbert-and-Sullivan-are-still.4348394.jp "Gilbert and Sullivan are still going strong after a century",] ''Sheffield Telegraph'', 1 August 2008</ref><ref name=history>[http://www.gs-festival.co.uk/history.aspx Festival history pages]</ref><ref name=Sandhamfest>Sandham, David. [http://www.s234171324.websitehome.co.uk/buxton_festivals.htm "Buxton Festivals"]. Buxton Festivals website with links to photos and reviews of each festival, accessed 19 September 2010</ref> On weeknights, the festival features a competition among amateur companies from all over the world.<ref>Beale, Robert. [http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/music/blow-down-gilbert--sullivan-5328030 "Blow me down! Gilbert & Sullivan bows out of Buxton"], ''Manchester Evening News'', 26 July 2013</ref><ref name=SkyArts>[http://www.skyarts.co.uk/theatre-drama/article/sky-arts-at-the-gilbert-and-sullivan-festival "Sky arts at the Gilbert and Sullivan Festival"]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. ''Sky Arts'', British Sky Broadcasting, accessed 13 August 2010</ref> On weekends, however, the festival offers professional performances given by companies such as the [[Carl Rosa Opera Company]], [[Opera della Luna]],<ref name=Sandhamfest/><ref name=Bradley193>Bradley, p. 193</ref> the [[New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players]],<ref name=Press2>Chalmers, Graham. [http://www.wetherbynews.co.uk/what-s-on/out-about/harrogate-wins-topsy-turvy-battle-over-g-s-festival-1-6657154 "Harrogate wins topsy-turvy battle over G&S Festival"], ''Wetherby News'', 5 June 2014; and Hutchinson, Charles. [http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/leisure/theatre/10925522.Gilbert_and_Sullivan_festival_in_Harrogate__August_2_to_26/ "Gilbert and Sullivan festival in Harrogate, August 2 to 26"], ''The Press'', 9 January 2014</ref> Charles Court Opera, and the festival's own National Gilbert & Sullivan Opera Company.<ref name=SkyArts/>
==History and description==
===Productions at the Gilbert and Sullivan Festival=== In 1995, the operators of the International Gilbert and Sullivan Festival formed an opera company to provide festivalgoers with professional productions of the Savoy operas.<ref>Spencer, Ted. [http://gsopera.com/company/gilbert-and-sullivan-opera-company-uk "The Gilbert and Sullivan Opera Company (UK)"], GSOpera.com, accessed 8 June 2014</ref> The company was soon called the Gilbert & Sullivan Opera Company. It engaged such performers as [[Richard Suart]], Simon Butteriss, Bruce Graham, [[Gillian Knight]], [[Barry Clark (singer)|Barry Clark]], [[Michael Rayner]], Jill Pert, Gareth Jones,<ref name=Bradley193/> [[Patricia Leonard]], [[Donald Maxwell (baritone)|Donald Maxwell]], Oliver White, Rebecca Bottone, [[Ian Belsey]] and the [[Opera Babes]]. John Owen Edwards, [[David Russell Hulme]], David Steadman or Andrew Nicklin have usually served as music directors for the company.<ref name=Telegraph/><ref name=history/><ref>Cockroft, Robert. [http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/music/Review-International-Gilbert-and-Sullivan.5555553.jp "Review: International Gilbert and Sullivan Festival",] ''Yorkshire Post'', 14 August 2009</ref> In 2014, the festival registered the company with [[Companies House]] as the National Gilbert & Sullivan Opera Company.<ref>[http://wck2.companieshouse.gov.uk//companysearch?disp=1&frfsh=1415737415&#result Company No. 09297497] filed with [[Companies House]] on 5 November 2014. See also: [https://www.facebook.com/197673590259673/photos/a.199298320097200.59081.197673590259673/970629616297396/?type=1&relevant_count=1 Announcement of name change], International Gilbert & Sullivan Festival, 11 November 2014</ref>
The company's performances are accompanied by the festival's National Festival Orchestra.<ref name=Press2/> It generally presents four productions each year at the festival, and the festival sells videos of most of its productions.<ref name=DVDs>[http://gsfestivals.org/shop/professional-shows "Professional Shows from the Festival"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140718023608/http://gsfestivals.org/shop/professional-shows |date=18 July 2014 }}, International Gilbert and Sullivan Festival, accessed 13 June 2014</ref><ref>[http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/culture/theatre/15321984.Theatre__Gilbert___Sullivan_heading_to_Harrogate_and_Newcastle "Theatre: Gilbert & Sullivan heading to Harrogate and Newcastle"], ''[[The Northern Echo]]'', 1 June 2017</ref> In 2018, in connection with the 25th anniversary of the International G&S Festival, the company is presenting six productions in Harrogate, Buxton and on tour.<ref>Smith, Ian. [https://issuu.com/gsfestival/docs/whatsonguideissu "What's On Guide 2018"], The International Gilbert & Sullivan Festival, accessed 2 July 2018; and [https://www.buxtonadvertiser.co.uk/whats-on/theatre-and-comedy/feast-of-g-and-s-is-heading-your-way-as-festival-returns-1-9214990 " Feast of G and S is heading your way as festival returns"], ''Buxton Advertiser'', 23 June 2018</ref>
[[File:The Royal Hall - geograph.org.uk - 652600.jpg|right|300px|thumb|The [[Royal Hall, Harrogate|Royal Hall]], [[Harrogate]], hosts the company's performances at the festival from 2014.]] Uniquely among professional companies in Britain, other than D'Oyly Carte, the National Gilbert & Sullivan Opera Company has presented all 13 of the extant Savoy Operas.<ref name=DVDs/> The company first performed ''[[Utopia, Limited]]'' in 2011, an opera that has rarely been given a professional staging in Britain over the past century.<ref name=UtopiaReview>Christiansen, Rupert. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/opera/8716483/Utopia-Ltd-Opera-House-Buxton-Opera-House-review.html "''Utopia Ltd'', Opera House"], ''The Telegraph'', 22 August 2011, accessed 17 February 2012</ref> In 2012 the company mounted the first full-scale professional production of ''[[The Grand Duke]]'' in Britain since the 19th century,<ref name=GDreview>[http://www.buxtonadvertiser.co.uk/lifestyle/g-s-co-take-festival-lead-1-4761370 "G&S Co take Festival Lead"], ''[[Buxton Advertiser]]'', 21 July 2012</ref> which was one of its four productions that year.<ref>[http://gsfestivals.org/content/2012-gs-opera-company-boxed-set "2012 G&S Opera Company Boxed Set"], International Gilbert and Sullivan Festival, accessed 13 June 2014</ref> Since 2013, the company has given up to 16 performances over the course of the festival at its new home in [[Harrogate]], England.<ref>Dreyer, Martin. [http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/news/14685271.Review__National_Gilbert___Sullivan_Opera_Company_in_The_Sorcerer_and_The_Yeomen_Of_The_Guard__Royal_Hall__Harrogate__August_12_and_13 "Review: National Gilbert & Sullivan Opera Company in ''The Sorcerer'' and ''The Yeomen of the Guard'', Royal Hall, Harrogate, August 12 and 13"], ''The Press'', 17 August 2016; and [http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/culture/theatre/15321984.Theatre__Gilbert___Sullivan_heading_to_Harrogate_and_Newcastle "Theatre: Gilbert & Sullivan heading to Harrogate and Newcastle"], ''[[The Northern Echo]]'', 1 June 2017</ref><ref>Wilkinson, Sue. [https://www.harrogateadvertiser.co.uk/whats-on/theatre-and-comedy/facts-and-figures-of-harrogate-s-g-s-festival-1-9083154 "Facts and figures of Harrogate’s G&S Festival", ''Harrogate Advertiser'', 26 March 2018</ref> In 2018, the company presented the first professional, fully staged production of ''[[Haddon Hall (opera)|Haddon Hall]]'' since the 19th century.<ref>Walker, Ramond J. [http://seenandheard-international.com/2018/08/haddon-hall-is-a-grundy-and-sullivan-rarity "Haddon Hall is a Grundy and Sullivan Rarity"], ''Seen and Heard International'', 4 August 2018; and Hall, George. [https://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/2018/haddon-hall-review-royal-hall-harrogate-rare-resuscitation-pedestrian-work "''Haddon Hall'' review at Royal Hall, Harrogate – 'rare resuscitation of Arthur Sullivan's pedestrian work'"], ''[[The Stage]]'', 21 August 2018</ref>
===Performances outside the festival=== In August and September 2010, the G&S Opera Company presented its first production outside of the festival, ''[[The Yeomen of the Guard]]'', at [[Oxford Castle]].<ref>Lisle, Nicola. [http://www.oxfordtimes.co.uk/archive/2010/08/19/8336547.Yeomen_of_the_Guard__Oxford_Castle/ "''Yeomen of the Guard'': Oxford Castle"]. ''The Oxford Times'', 19 August 2010, accessed 13 June 2014</ref><ref>Christiansen, Rupert. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/7977089/The-Yeoman-of-the-Guard-Oxford-Castle-review.html "The Yeoman of the Guard, Oxford Castle, review"]. ''The Telegraph'', 2 September 2010</ref> Two of its 2012 productions were repeated in [[Harrogate]] late in August,<ref>[http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/leisure/theatre/9828956.ClassicFest__Royal_Hall__Harrogate__August_21_to_27/ "ClassicFest, Royal Hall, Harrogate, August 21 to 27"], ''The Press'', 20 July 2012</ref> and all three of its 2013 productions transferred there in late August.<ref>[http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/leisure/theatre/10586233.ClassicFest__Royal_Hall_and_Harrogate_Theatre__August_18_to_31/ "ClassicFest, Royal Hall and Harrogate Theatre, August 18 to 31"], ''The Press'', 1 August 2013</ref> The company toured three of its 2014 productions in repertory from June to August 2014, giving seven performances in each of six cities.<ref>Potter, Tully. [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2387642/Iolanthe-Poking-fun-peers-G-amp-S-style.html "''Iolanthe'': Poking fun at the peers, G&S style"], ''Daily Mail'', 9 August 2013</ref><ref>Smith, Ian. [http://gsfestivals.org/content/gs-opera-co-tour "G&S Opera Co on Tour"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140303204528/http://gsfestivals.org/content/gs-opera-co-tour |date=3 March 2014 }}, The International Gilbert and Sullivan Festival, accessed 8 June 2014</ref> Since 2015, besides Harrogate, the company has toured its productions to several cities and towns in the UK,<ref>Bratby, Richard. [http://www.theartsdesk.com/opera/hms-pinafore-national-gilbert-sullivan-opera-company "''HMS Pinafore'', National Gilbert & Sullivan Opera Company"], ''The Arts Desk'', 10 August 2015; Bratby, Richard. [http://www.theartsdesk.com/opera/yeomen-guard-national-gilbert-sullivan-opera-company "The Yeomen of the Guard, National Gilbert & Sullivan Opera Company"], TheArtsDesk.com, 2 August 2016; and Bratby, Richard. [http://www.theartsdesk.com/opera/princess-ida-national-gilbert-sullivan-opera-company-review-sparkling-comedy-wobbly-sets "Princess Ida, National Gilbert & Sullivan Opera Company review – sparkling comedy, wobbly sets"], TheArtsDesk.com, 1 September 2017</ref><ref>[http://gsopera.org/content/tour-dates "2017 Tour Dates"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170824150453/http://gsopera.org/content/tour-dates# |date=24 August 2017 }}, International Gilbert and Sullivan Festival, accessed 15 May 2017</ref> including the Festival's previous home, Buxton.<ref name=Buxton2015>Beale, Robert. [http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/music-nightlife-news/gondoliers-buxton-opera-house-review-9806270 "''The Gondoliers'' at Buxton Opera House review"], ''Manchester Evening News'', 7 August 2015</ref>
==Reception== ''[[Sky Arts]]'' called the Gilbert & Sullivan Opera Company's performers "some of the UK's finest exponents of musical theatre".<ref name=SkyArts/> The ''[[Mail Online]]'' gave the company's ''[[The Mikado]]'' four stars.<ref>Gore-langton, Robert. [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/reviews/article-1304540/Yum-yum-Mikado-thats-utterly-delicious.html?ito=feeds-newsxml "Yum-yum, a Mikado that's utterly delicious"]. ''[[Mail Online]]'', 20 August 2010</ref> A review of the company's 2010 production of ''[[Iolanthe]]'', noted, "The music was up to [the festival's] usual high standard, with the orchestra ... giving a superb and sprightly reading of the Overture and score throughout."<ref name=Iolanthe2010/><ref>[http://gsfestivals.org/content/2010-gs-opera-company-boxed-set "2010 G&S Opera Company Boxed Set"], International Gilbert and Sullivan Festival, accessed 13 June 2014</ref> Another reviewer of that production commented: With a reputation for strong casts [and] energetic delivery, traditionally fresh interpretations are brought to [the] roles. ... Care is always taken with the staging and lighting of these ... productions and, as with ''[[Princess Ida]]'' last year, they can match a [[West End theatre|West End]] show. ... Throughout, the chorus was outstanding.<ref name=Iolanthe2010>Walker, Raymond J. [http://www.musicweb-international.com/SandH/2010/Jul-Dec10/iolanthe3107.htm "Buxton International Gilbert and Sullivan Festival 2010 - Iolanthe"]. Seen and Heard International, MusicWeb International, accessed 6 August 2010</ref> ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' "thoroughly enjoyed [the company's] spirited production" of ''Utopia, Limited'' in 2011.<ref name=UtopiaReview/> A reviewer said of their 2013 production of ''Princess Ida'', "the performance sparkled; singing, acting, costumes, dramatic flow and orchestral playing were all splendid".<ref>King, Andrew H. [http://bachtrack.com/review-buxton-gilbert-and-sullivan-festival-princess-ida "Buxton Gilbert and Sullivan Festival's remarkable Princess Ida"], Bachtrack.com, 22 August 2013, accessed 28 June 2014</ref>
A review of the company's 2014 tour praised the direction, choreography and conducting of ''[[The Pirates of Penzance]]'' and continued: "They are a real find with strong production values, a great orchestra and first class singing. ... It all looks marvellous with picture book settings and eye catching costumes plus a full and energetic cast. ... The chorus work is top notch, and they all come across as individuals."<ref>Key, Philip. [http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/whats-on/arts-culture-news/pirates-penzance-floral-pavilion-new-7255224 "Review: The Pirates of Penzance at the Floral Pavilion, New Brighton"], ''[[Liverpool Echo]]'', 11 June 2014; another review gave the production five stars. Marston, Paul. [http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/whats-on/arts-culture-news/review-pirates-penzance-wolverhampton-grand-7322097 "Review: ''The Pirates of Penzance'' at Wolverhampton Grand Theatre"], ''Birmingham Mail'', 25 June 2014</ref> The ''[[Birmingham Mail]]'' liked the cast, costumes and "infectious" humour of the company's ''Iolanthe''<ref>Marston, Paul. [http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/whats-on/arts-culture-news/review-iolanthe-wolverhampton-grand-theatre-7336041 "Review: ''Iolanthe'' at Wolverhampton Grand Theatre"], ''Birmingham Mail'', 27 June 2014</ref> and called its production of ''The Mikado'' "superb", praising the principal cast, chorus and orchestra, but was disappointed in "the decision to make the Mikado ... a fun figure rather than a scary ruler."<ref>Marston, Paul. [http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/whats-on/arts-culture-news/review-mikado-wolverhampton-grand-theatre-7343910 "Review: ''The Mikado'' at Wolverhampton Grand Theatre"], ''Birmingham Mail'', 30 June 2014</ref> The company's ''Iolanthe'' made a Gilbert and Sullivan fan out of a sceptical reviewer.<ref>[http://www.teesdalemercury.co.uk/Articles/2014/review-of-iolanthe---darlington-civic-theatre "Review of Iolanthe – Darlington Civic Theatre"], ''Teesdale Mercury'', 1 July 2014</ref> The ''[[Daily Express]]'' reviewer said that the company provided "glorious musical entertainment",<ref>Hartston, William. [http://www.express.co.uk/entertainment/theatre/496380/The-Mikado-and-HMS-Pinafore-opera-reviews-at-International-Gilbert-Sullivan-Festival "''The Mikado'' and ''HMS Pinafore'' opera reviews: Polished, zany and 'deliciously camp'"], ''Daily Express'', 8 August 2014</ref> and the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' gave the company five stars.<ref>Potter, Tully. [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2719477/Hurrah-fun-frivolous-English-TULLY-POTTER-reviews-Gilbert-Sullivan-Festival.html "Hurrah for the fun and frivolous English"], ''The Daily Mail'', 8 August 2014</ref> ''[[The Northern Echo]]'' reviewed the 2015 tour, stating: "This company is so polished, so well-versed in the eccentricities of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, with excellent singing voices coupled with clear diction ... and comedic skill. ... [A] tuneful, jolly, laugh-out-loud evening’s entertainment.<ref>Heath, Sue. [http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/entertainment/13754551.The_Mikado__Darlington_Civic_Theatre/ "''The Mikado'', Darlington Civic Theatre"], ''[[The Northern Echo]]'', 16 September 2015</ref> ''[[The Manchester Evening News]]'' gave the company four out of five stars, admiring its musical and comic polish, dancing and "magnificent" chorus.<ref name=Buxton2015/>
In 2017, a reviewer praised the principals and chorus of the company's ''Mikado'' production, commenting: "This is giggle-making, girth-busting comic opera at it's very best. Sensational singing with sumptuous scenery."<ref>Thomas, Paul. [http://www.localberkshire.co.uk/news/15426457.Theatre_bows_out_for_two_weeks___with_a_Gilbert_and_Sullivan_feast "''The Mikado'' at Windsor – a 'yum-yum' of an operatta"], ''Local Berkshire'', Newsquest Media Group, 21 July 2017</ref> A review of their ''Princess Ida'' was likewise effusive.<ref>Mogridge, Geoffrey. [http://www.ilkleygazette.co.uk/leisure/leisure_ents/15473362.Review__The_National_Gilbert___Sullivan_Company__39_s_Princess_Ida__Royal_Hall__Harrogate_Saturday__August_12__2017/?ref=rss "Review: The National Gilbert & Sullivan Company's ''Princess Ida'', Royal Hall, Harrogate: Saturday, August 12, 2017"], ''[[Ilkley Gazette]]'', 15 August 2017</ref>
==Recordings== Recordings of the company's productions are sold by the Festival on DVD.<ref>[http://gsfestivals.org/shop/professional-shows Recordings available on DVD] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140718023608/http://gsfestivals.org/shop/professional-shows |date=18 July 2014 }}, International Gilbert and Sullivan Festival, accessed 13 June 2014</ref> Some of the productions are also available on CD.<ref>[http://gsfestivals.org/shop/cds Recordings available on CD] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140718022725/http://www.gsfestivals.org/shop/cds |date=18 July 2014 }}, International Gilbert and Sullivan Festival, accessed 26 June 2014</ref>
==See also== *[[:Category:Gilbert and Sullivan performers|Gilbert and Sullivan performers]]
==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}}
==References== *{{Cite book| last = Bradley | first = Ian| title = Oh Joy! Oh Rapture! The Enduring Phenomenon of Gilbert and Sullivan |location=New York| publisher = Oxford University Press | year = 2005 | isbn = 0-19-516700-7}} *{{Cite book|last=Joseph|first=Tony|year=1994|title=D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, 1875–1982: An Unofficial History|location=London|publisher=Bunthorne Books}} {{ISBN|0-9507992-1-1}}
==External links== *[https://www.ngsoc.org/?mc_cid=48ceeca4e5&mc_eid=b882e9c1ee Official website]

{{featured article}} {{Spanish name|Sánchez|Garzón}} {{Infobox person | name = Omayra Sánchez | image = Omayra Sanchez.jpg | image_size = 300px | caption = [[Frank Fournier]]'s photograph of Omayra Sánchez | birth_name = Omayra Sánchez Garzón | birth_date = {{birth date|1972|08|29}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{Death date and age|1985|11|16|1972|08|29}} | death_place = [[Armero]], [[Tolima Department|Tolima]], Colombia | death_cause = Killed by the [[Armero tragedy|volcanic eruption]] of Nevado del Ruiz | nationality = Colombian | parents = Alvaro Enrique Sánchez
Maria Aleida Garzón }} '''Omayra Sánchez Garzón''' (August 28, 1972 – November 16, 1985) was a 13-year-old Colombian girl killed in [[Armero]], [[Tolima Department|Tolima]], by the [[Armero tragedy|1985 eruption]] of the [[Nevado del Ruiz]] volcano. Volcanic debris mixed with ice to form massive [[lahar]]s (volcanically induced [[mudflow]]s, [[landslide]]s, and [[debris flow]]s) that rushed into the river valleys below the mountain, killing nearly 23,000 people and destroying Armero and 13 other villages. After a lahar demolished her home, Sánchez was pinned beneath the debris of her house, where she remained trapped in water for three days. Her plight was documented as she descended from calmness into agony. Her courage and dignity touched journalists and relief workers, who put great efforts into comforting her. After 60 hours of struggling, she died, likely as a result of either [[gangrene]] or [[hypothermia]]. Her death highlighted the failure of officials to respond correctly to the threat of the volcano, contrasted with the efforts of volunteer rescue workers to reach and treat trapped victims, despite inadequate supplies and equipment. A photograph of Sánchez taken by the photojournalist [[Frank Fournier]] shortly before she died was published in news outlets around the world. It was later designated the [[World Press Photo of the Year]] for 1985. Sánchez has remained a lasting figure in popular culture, remembered through music, literature, and commemorative articles. == Background == {{main article|Armero tragedy}} On November 13, 1985, the [[Nevado del Ruiz]] volcano erupted. At 9:09 pm of that night, [[pyroclastic flow]]s exploding from the crater melted the mountain's icecap, forming lahars (volcanic mudflows and debris flows) which cascaded into river valleys below. One lahar, consisting of three pulses, did most of the damage. Traveling at {{convert|6|m|ft|0|sp=us}} per second, the first pulse enveloped most of the town of [[Armero]], killing up to 20,000 people; the two later pulses weakened buildings. Another lahar killed 1,800 people in nearby [[Chinchiná, Caldas|Chinchiná]].{{harvnb|Martí|Ernst|2005|p=291}} In total 23,000 people were killed and 13 villages in addition to Armero were destroyed.{{cite news |title=Rescuers in Colombia refuse to give up hunt for survivors |date=November 18, 1985 |work=[[Milwaukee Journal]] |publisher= }} [[File:Armero aftermath Marso.jpg|left|thumb|Formerly in the center of this area, the town of Armero was buried by thick volcanic mudflows in 1985.]] Loss of life was exacerbated by the authorities' failure to take costly preventive measures in the absence of clear signs of imminent danger. There had been no substantial eruption of the volcano since 1845, which contributed to complacency; locals called the volcano the "Sleeping Lion".{{cite news |title=BBC:On this day: November 13: 1985: Volcano kills thousands in Colombia |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/november/13/newsid_2539000/2539731.stm | work=[[BBC News Online]] |publisher=[[BBC]]|date=November 13, 1985 |accessdate=September 3, 2009}} In September 1985, as earthquakes and [[phreatic eruption]]s rocked the area around the volcano, officials began planning for evacuation. A hazard map was prepared in October;{{#tag:ref|This was the first hazard map ever prepared for a [[List of volcanoes in Colombia|Colombian volcano]].|group=nb}} it highlighted the danger from falling ash and [[volcanic rock|rock]] near [[Murillo, Tolima|Murillo]], [[Santa Isabel, Tolima|Santa Isabel]], and [[Líbano, Tolima|Líbano]], as well as the threat of lahars in [[Mariquita, Tolima|Mariquita]], [[Armero-Guayabal|Guayabal]], Chinchiná, and Armero.{{cite web |url=http://desastres.unanleon.edu.ni/pdf/2004/octubre/PDF/ENG/DOC4377/doc4377-contenido.pdf |title=Eruption of El Ruiz Volcano, Colombia |last=Gueri |first=Miguel |date=October 2004 |publisher=[[National Autonomous University of Nicaragua]]-León. p. 50 |accessdate=July 22, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724143331/http://desastres.unanleon.edu.ni/pdf/2004/octubre/PDF/ENG/DOC4377/doc4377-contenido.pdf |archivedate=July 24, 2011 |df= }} The map was poorly distributed to those at highest risk: many survivors had never heard of it, though several major newspapers had featured it.{{harvnb|Villegas|2003|p=5}} Henry Villegas of the Colombian Institute of Mining and Geology stated that the maps clearly demonstrated Armero would be affected by the lahars, but had "met with strong opposition from economic interests." He said that the short time between the map's preparation and the eruption hindered timely distribution.{{harvnb|Villegas|2003|p=6}} The Colombian Congress criticised scientific and [[civil defense]] agencies for scaremongering, and the government and army were preoccupied with the [[Colombian armed conflict (1964–present)|guerrilla campaign]] in [[Bogotá]], the national capital, which was then at its height.{{cite web |url=http://hvo.wr.usgs.gov/volcanowatch/2009/09_10_29.html |author=Hawaiian Volcano Observatory |title=Lessons Learned from the Armero, Colombia Tragedy |date=November 29, 2009 |publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]] |accessdate=July 20, 2010}} The death toll was increased by the lack of early warnings,{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/science/horizon/2001/volcanohelltrans.shtml |title=Volcano Hell Transcript |last=Fielding |first=Emma |work=[[BBC Television]] |publisher=[[BBC]] |accessdate=September 3, 2008}} unwise land use, as villages were built in the likely path of lahars, and the lack of preparedness in communities near the volcano. Colombia's worst natural disaster,{{cite news |author=Staff |title=World News Briefs |url=http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/Newsbriefs/9511/11-14/index.html |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=November 14, 1995 |accessdate=September 20, 2008}} the [[Armero tragedy]] (as it came to be known) was the second-deadliest volcanic disaster of the 20th century (surpassed only by the 1902 eruption of [[Mount Pelée]]).{{cite web |url=http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/hazard/stratoguide/nevadofact.html |title=Nevado del Ruiz – Facts and Figures |publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] |last=Staff |accessdate=September 3, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080925165636/http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/hazard/stratoguide/nevadofact.html |archivedate=September 25, 2008 |deadurl=no}} It was the fourth-deadliest eruption recorded since 1500 AD.{{cite web|url=http://vulcan.wr.usgs.gov/LivingWith/VolcanicFacts/deadly_eruptions.html|title=Deadliest Volcanic Eruptions Since 1500 A.D.|last=Topinka |first=Lyn |publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]] |accessdate=September 20, 2008}} Its lahars were the deadliest in volcanic history. == Life == Omayra Sánchez lived in the neighborhood of Santander with her parents Álvaro Enrique, a rice and [[sorghum]] collector, and María Aleida, along with her brother Álvaro Enrique and aunt María Adela Garzón.{{harvnb|Barragán|1987}} Prior to the eruption, her mother had traveled to Bogotá on business. The night of the disaster, Omayra and her family were awake, worrying about the ashfall from the eruption, when they heard the sound of an approaching lahar. After it hit, Omayra became trapped under her home's concrete and other debris and could not free herself. When rescue teams tried to help her, they realized that her legs were trapped under her house's roof.{{cite news |title=Trapped Girl, 13, Dies |work=[[The New York Times]] |publisher=[[Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, Jr.]] |date=November 17, 1985}} Sources differ as to the degree to which Sánchez was trapped. Zeiderman (2009) said she was "trapped up to her neck",{{harvnb|Zeiderman|2009|p=10}} while Barragán (1987) said that she was trapped up to her waist. For the first few hours after the mudflow hit, she was covered by concrete but got her hand through a crack in the debris. After a rescuer noticed her hand protruding from a pile of debris, he and others cleared tiles and wood over the course of a day. Once the girl was freed from the waist up, her rescuers attempted to pull her out, but found the task impossible without breaking her legs in the process. Each time a person pulled her, the water pooled around her, rising so that it seemed she would drown if they let her go, so rescue workers placed a tire around her body to keep her afloat. Divers discovered that Sánchez's legs were caught under a door made of bricks, with her aunt's arms clutched tightly around her legs and feet. == Death == {{Quote box |quoted=true |bgcolor=#F5F6CE |salign=left| quote = Colombia and half of the world remained with the bitter sensation that Omayra Sánchez could have been able to continue living after remaining for almost 60 hours trapped from head to toe amidst the rubble of Armero. Her face, her words, and her courage, which streamed throughout the world on television and were a heartbreaking image in the largest newspapers and magazines of the United States and Europe, remained a testimony of accusation against those who could have at the very least made the tragedy less serious. Germán Santa María Barragán in ''[[El Tiempo (Colombia)|El Tiempo]]'', November 23, 1985|align= right|width=300px}} Despite her predicament, Sánchez remained relatively positive: she sang to [[Germán Santa María Barragán]], a journalist who was working as a volunteer, asked for sweet food, drank soda, and agreed to be interviewed. At times, she was scared, and prayed or cried.{{cite news |publisher=[[Canadian Journalism Foundation]] |work=Canadian Journalism Project |last=Lacey |first=Dana |title=Why We Don't Cover Pakistan |date=August 31, 2010}} On the third night, Sánchez began [[hallucination|hallucinating]], saying that she did not want to be late for school, and mentioned a maths exam.{{harvnb|Barragán|1994|p=7}} Near the end of her life, Sánchez's eyes reddened, her face swelled, and her hands whitened. At one point she asked the people to leave her so they could rest. Hours later the workers returned with a pump and tried to save her, but her legs were bent under the concrete as if she was kneeling, and it was impossible to free her without severing her legs. Lacking the surgical equipment to save her from the effects of an amputation, the doctors present agreed that it would be more humane to let her die. In all, Sánchez suffered for nearly three nights (roughly 60 hours) before she died at approximately 10:05 A.M. on November 16 from exposure,{{Cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/4231020.stm |title=Picture power: Tragedy of Omayra Sanchez |date=September 30, 2005 |work=[[BBC News Online]] | publisher= [[BBC]] |accessdate=September 28, 2010}} most likely from [[gangrene]] or [[hypothermia]]. Her brother survived the lahars; her father and aunt died. Her mother expressed her feelings about Omayra's death: "It is horrible, but we have to think about the living ... I will live for my son, who only lost a finger."{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=TX5WAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QEENAAAAIBAJ&pg=3684,440325 |title=Ordeal Ends in Death |work=[[Leader-Post]] |publisher=Postmedia Network Inc. |date=November 18, 1985 |accessdate=April 19, 2011}} As the public became aware of Sánchez's situation through the media, her death became a symbol of the failure of officials to properly assist victims who could have been saved. Controversy broke out after descriptions of the shortages were released in newspapers, disproving what officials had previously indicated: that they had used the best of their supplies. Volunteer relief workers said that there was such a lack of resources that supplies as basic as shovels, cutting tools, and stretchers ran out. The rescue process was impeded by large crowds and disorganization. An unnamed police officer said that the government should have depended on human resources to alleviate the problems and that the system of rescue was disorganized.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fbdQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3RMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5678,7662718& |title=Colombian officials defend rescue effort; lack of equipment blamed |work=[[Star-News]] |publisher=Bob Gruber |date=November 24, 1985 |accessdate=November 24, 2010}} Colombia's Minister of Defense, Miguel Uribe, said he "understood criticism of the rescue effort", but said that Colombia was "an undeveloped country" that did not "have that kind of equipment." == Photograph == Frank Fournier, a French reporter who landed in Bogotá on November 15, took a photograph of Sánchez in her final days, titled "The Agony of Omayra Sánchez".{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Mq8yAAAAIBAJ&sjid=me8FAAAAIBAJ&pg=3433,3016148 |title=Ottawa Man Third |date=February 7, 1986 |accessdate=April 19, 2011 |work=[[Ottawa Citizen]] |publisher=James Orban}} When he reached Armero at dawn on the 16th, a farmer directed him to Sánchez, who by then had been trapped for nearly three days and was near-deserted. Fournier later described the town as "very haunting," with "eerie silence" punctuated by screaming. He said that he took the photograph feeling that he could only "report properly on the courage and the suffering and the dignity of the little girl" in his attempt to publicize the disaster's need for relief efforts, feeling otherwise "powerless".{{harvnb|Zeiderman|2009|p=14}} At the time, there was international awareness of the disaster. Sánchez was one of the victims at the center of the associated controversy over responsibility for the destructive aftermath. The image captured international attention. According to an unnamed BBC reporter, "Many were appalled at witnessing so intimately what transpired to be the last few hours of Omayra's life." After the photo was published in ''[[Paris Match]],'' many accused Fournier of being "a vulture." He responded,
"I felt the story was important for me to report and I was happier that there was some reaction; it would have been worse if people had not cared about it. ... I believe the photo helped raise money from around the world in aid and helped highlight the irresponsibility and lack of courage of the country's leaders."
The picture later won the [[World Press Photo of the Year]] for 1985.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PEYsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2s4EAAAAIBAJ&pg=6813,1694667 |title=World Photo Award |date=February 7, 1986 |accessdate=April 19, 2011 |work=[[Spartanburg Herald-Journal]] |publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]}} == Legacy == The Armero catastrophe came shortly after the [[19th of April Movement|M-19]] guerrilla group's raid and subsequent [[Palace of Justice siege]] on November 6, worsening an already chaotic situation. After Sánchez's death, blame for it and for the Armero tragedy fell on the Colombian government for its inaction and general indifference to warning signs prior to the volcano's eruption.{{cite web |url=http://www.geology.sdsu.edu/how_volcanoes_work/Nevado.html |title=Nevado del Ruiz (1985) |last=Camp |first=Vic |publisher=[[San Diego State University]] |date=March 31, 2006 |accessdate=September 3, 2008}} The Nevado del Ruiz volcano is still active, according to the Volcano Watch Center in Colombia. Melting only 10 percent of the ice would produce mudflows with a volume of up to {{convert|200000000|m3|cuft|sigfig=3|sp=us}}—similar to the mudflow that destroyed Armero in 1985.{{cite journal |last1=Huggel |first1=Cristian |last2=Ceballos |first2=Jorge Luis |last3=Pulgarín |first3=Bernardo |last4=Ramírez |first4=Jair |last5=Thouret |first5=Jean-Claude |title=Review and reassessment of hazards owing to volcano–glacier interactions in Colombia |year=2007 |volume=45 |journal=Annals of Glaciology |pages=128–136 |url=http://www.igsoc.org/annals/45/a45A019.pdf |doi=10.3189/172756407782282408 |format=pdf |accessdate=April 20, 2011 |bibcode = 2007AnGla..45..128H }} Such [[lahar]]s can travel up to {{convert|100|km|mi|0|sp=us}} along river valleys in a few hours. Estimates show that up to 500,000 people living in the Combeima, Chinchiná, Coello-Toche, and Guali valleys are at risk, and 100,000 of these are considered to be at high risk.{{cite conference |last1=Thouret |first1=Jean-Claude |last2=Murcia |first2=A |last3=Salinas |first3=R. |last4=Parra |first4=E. |last5=Cepeda |first5=H. |last6=Cantagrel |first6=J-M. |title=Stratigraphy and quaternary eruptive history of the Ruiz-Tolima volcanic massif, Colombia. Implications for assessement of volcanic hazards |year=1990 |conference=Symposium international géodynamique andine: résumés des communications |place=Paris |pages=391–393 |url=http://horizon.documentation.ird.fr/exl-doc/pleins_textes/pleins_textes_4/colloques/31077.pdf |format=PDF|subscription=yes}} The city of Armero no longer exists. The site was commemorated as a memorial with [[Christian cross]]es and a small monument to Sánchez.{{cite news|title=Survivors of avalanche relive tragedy through TV movie |last=Johnson |first=Tim |date=September 18, 1997 |work=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]] |publisher=[[Journal Communications]]}} In the years following the eruption, Sánchez has been repeatedly commemorated, especially in newspapers like ''El Tiempo''.{{harvnb|Zeiderman|2009|pp=12–13}} Many victims of the disaster were commemorated, but Sánchez in particular has attracted lasting attention in popular poetry, novels, and music.{{harvnb|Zeiderman|2009|p=12}} For example, a [[punk rock]] band formed in Chile in 2008 named themselves Omayra Sánchez; they express their "discontent that they feel with the negligence on the part of the people who in this day and age run the world".{{harvnb|Zeiderman|2009|p=13}} ''Adiós, Omayra: La catástrofe de Armero'' (1988), written by [[Eduardo Santa]] as a response to the eruption, depicts the girl's last days of life in detail and cites her in its introduction as an eternal symbol of the catastrophe. In ''No Morirás'' (1994), Germán Santa María Barragán writes that of all the horrors he saw at Armero, nothing was more painful than seeing the face of Omayra Sánchez under the ruins of her house. [[Isabel Allende]]'s [[short story]], "And of Clay Are We Created" ("De barro estamos hechos"), is told from the perspective of a reporter who tries to help a girl trapped under the fireplace of her ruined home. Allende later wrote, "Her [Sánchez's] big black eyes, filled with resignation and wisdom, still pursue me in my dreams. Writing the story failed to exorcise her ghost."{{harvnb|Correas de Zapata |Sayers Peden|2002|p=76}} To try to prevent repetition of such a disaster, the government of Colombia created the ''Oficina Nacional para la Atención de Desastres'' (National Office for Disaster Preparedness), now known as the ''Dirección de Prevención y Atención de Desastres'' (Directorate for Disaster Prevention and Preparedness).{{cite web |url=http://www.dnp.gov.co/PortalWeb/Programas/ViviendaAguaDesarrolloUrbanoAmbiente/Gesti%C3%B3ndelRiesgo/Direcci%C3%B3ndePrevenci%C3%B3nyAtenci%C3%B3ndeDesastres.aspx |title=Dirección de Prevención y Atención de Desastres — DPAD |date=June 24, 2010 |publisher=Departamento Nacional de Planeación, República de Colombia |accessdate=September 1, 2010 |language=Spanish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002214757/http://www.dnp.gov.co/PortalWeb/Programas/ViviendaAguaDesarrolloUrbanoAmbiente/Gesti%C3%B3ndelRiesgo/Direcci%C3%B3ndePrevenci%C3%B3nyAtenci%C3%B3ndeDesastres.aspx |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |df= }} All Colombian cities were directed to plan for natural disasters.{{cite journal |last1=Touret |first1=Jean-Claude |last2=Laforge |first2=Christophe |title=Hazard Appraisal and Hazard-Zone Mapping of Flooding and Debris Flowage in the Rio Combeima Valley and Ibague City, Tolima Department, Colombia |journal=GeoJournal |year=1994 |volume=34 |issue=4 |pages=407–413 |url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/j7h51t87x7201375 |accessdate=August 31, 2010}} == Notes == {{Reflist|group=nb}} == References == {{Reflist|colwidth=35em}} === Sources === {{Spoken Wikipedia|EN-Omayra_Sánchez.ogg|2013-08-27}} *{{cite book |url=http://www.banrepcultural.org/blaavirtual/politica/sangres/nina.htm |title=Colombia y Otras Sangres |year=1987 |last=Barragán |first=Germán Santa María |publisher=[[University of Texas]] |language=Spanish |isbn=978-958-614-248-9 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011031151/http://www.banrepcultural.org/blaavirtual/politica/sangres/nina.htm |archivedate=2012-10-11 |df= |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last=Barragán |first=Germán Santa María |title=No Morirás |publisher=Andres Bollo |year=1994 |isbn=978-958-06-0084-8|ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last1=Correas de Zapata |first1=Celia |last2=Sayers Peden |first2=Margaret | title=Isabel Allende: Life and Spirits |year=2002 |publisher=Arte Publico Press |isbn=978-1-55885-363-8|ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last1=Martí |first1=Joan |last2=Ernst |first2=Gerald |title=Volcanoes and the Environment |year=2005 |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |isbn=978-0-521-59725-8|ref=harv}} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/10106040308542276 |last=Villegas |first=Henry <!-- No infobox please. Use British English --> [[File:Judith mit dem Haupt des Holofernes.jpg|right|thumb|''Judith with the Head of Holofernes'' by [[Lucas Cranach the Elder]], 1530]] [[File:Area mosana, acquamanile con aristotele e phyllis, xv sec..JPG|thumb|15th-century [[aquamanile]] with [[The tale of Phyllis and Aristotle|Phyllis riding Aristotle]] <ref>{{cite web|title=Aquamanile in the Form of Aristotle and Phyllis|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search/459202|publisher=[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]}}</ref>]] [[File:Jacopo Amigoni 002.jpg|thumb|[[Jacopo Amigoni]], [[Jael]] and [[Sisera]], 1739]]
The '''"Power of Women"''' (''Weibermacht'' in German) is a medieval and Renaissance artistic and [[literary topos]], showing "heroic or wise men dominated by women", presenting "an admonitory and often humorous inversion of the male-dominated sexual hierarchy".<ref>Ainsworth, p. 59</ref> It was defined by [[Susan L. Smith]] as "the representational practice of bringing together at least two, but usually more, well-known figures from the Bible, ancient history, or romance to exemplify a cluster of interrelated themes that include the wiles of women, the power of love, and the trials of marriage".<ref>{{cite journal|last=Babinsky|first=Elen L.|year=1997|title=Rev. of Smith, ''The Power of Women'' |journal=[[American Society of Church History |Church History]] |volume=66 |issue=2 |pages=340–341 |doi=10.2307/3170688 |url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=2298424}}</ref> Smith argues that the topos is not simply a "straightforward manifestation of medieval antifeminism"; rather, it is "a site of contest through which conflicting ideas about gender roles could be expressed".<ref>{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Susan L.|editor=Margaret Schaus|title=Women and Gender in Medieval Europe: An Encyclopedia |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aDhOv6hgN2IC&pg=PA845 |year=2006|publisher=Taylor & Francis |isbn=978-0415969444 |pages=844–845}}</ref><ref>''c.f.'' Nurse p. 1, who characterises it as arising from the complex religious and social turmoil provoked by the European Reformation of the sixteenth century.</ref>
Smith argues the topos originates in classical literature<ref>{{cite journal |last=Millett |first=Bella |date=22 September 1997 |title=Rev. of Smith, ''The Power of Women'' |journal=[[Medium Aevum]] |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/The+Power+of+Women%3A+A+%27Topos%27+in+Medieval+Art+and+Literature.-a020331549}}</ref> and finds it in medieval texts such as ''[[Aucassin et Nicolette]]'', ''[[The Consolation of Philosophy]]'', the ''[[Roman de la Rose]]'', and the ''[[Canterbury Tales]]''.<ref name=Harp208>Harp p. 208</ref> The topos was attacked by [[Christine de Pizan]] around 1400, who argued that if women wrote these accounts their interpretations would be different from those of men.<ref name= Wolfthal>Wolfthal p. 57</ref>
In the visual arts, images are found in various media, mainly from the 14th century onwards, and becoming increasingly popular in the 15th century. By then the frequently recurring subjects include [[Judith beheading Holofernes]], [[The tale of Phyllis and Aristotle|Phyllis riding Aristotle]], [[Samson in popular culture#Art|Samson and Delilah]], [[Salome]] and her mother [[Herodias]], [[Jael]] killing [[Sisera]], [[Bathsheba]] bathing in sight of [[David]], the idolatry of [[Solomon]], [[Virgil in his basket]], as well as many depictions of witches, and genre images of wives dominating their husbands. The last group came to be called the '''battle for the trousers'''.<ref>Salomon, 87; "''strijd om de broek''" in sixteenth century Netherlandish literature and printmaking.</ref> [[Joseph (patriarch)|Joseph]] and [[Potiphar|Potiphar's wife]] and [[Lot (biblical person)#Lot and his daughters|Lot and his Daughters]] were somewhat late joiners to the group, but increasingly popular later on.<ref>Russell, pp. 147–148, Nos 20–32 (Judith), 87–110, 120–125; Ainsworth, pp. 59–66; Salomon, pp. 87–88; Hall, 41–42</ref> [[Tomyris]], the [[Scythian]] queen who defeated [[Cyrus the Great]] and abused his corpse, was painted by Rubens and several Italians.<ref>Hall, 305</ref>
These scenes, mostly shown in consistent compositions involving just two persons and visually distinctive actions, were easily recognisable and seem to have also been represented dramatically in entertainments of various sorts, whether as short scenes or [[tableaux vivants]].<ref>Snyder, 461</ref> It is not clear who first coined the term ''Weibermacht'', but it had evidently gained currency in the sixteenth century [[Northern Renaissance]] in Germany and the Low Countries.<ref>Nurse p. 1</ref>
==Visual arts==
In early images from the Gothic period genre subjects or "classical" ones such as ''Phyllis Riding Aristotle'' and ''Virgil in his Basket'', in fact both medieval legendary accretions, were more popular than the biblical ones predominating later. They often appear on the same pieces as the [[Assault on the Castle of Love]], as on a [[Casket with Scenes of Romances (Walters 71264)|casket in Baltimore]]. This and similar subjects of [[courtly love]] mostly survive on ivory objects for female use, such as caskets or mirror-cases. It shows ladies defending a castle against men, generally unsuccessfully.<ref>[[:File:A woman defends her castle.jpg|But not always]]. More typically the only real resistance is Cupid firing arrows.</ref> These images are essentially light-hearted romantic fantasy given a comic treatment; such scenes were sometimes staged as light relief at [[tournament]]s.<ref>[[Roger Sherman Loomis|Loomis, Roger Sherman]], "The Allegorical Siege in the Art of the Middle Ages", ''American Journal of Archaeology'', Vol. 23, No. 3 (Jul.–Sep., 1919), pp. 255–269,[https://www.jstor.org/stable/497460 JSTOR (free)]</ref>
The Power of Women theme is especially popular in [[Northern Renaissance]] art from the sixteenth century, which depicts "images drawn from historical, mythological, and biblical sources that illustrate women's power over men, specifically as a result of their sexual attractiveness".<ref>Salomon, 87</ref> Several of the stories involve the killing of the male, and this and their religious context effectively remove much of the comic potential of the group, but by no means the erotic possibilites exploited by many artists.
The question of the attitudes shown towards violence by women in the cause of virtue is perhaps best seen in the figure of [[Jael]], whose killing of Sisera by hammering a tent peg into his head makes an especially graphic image. According to some feminist critics, depictions of her turned hostile in the Renaissance, and like Judith she is certainly grouped with "bad" figures such as Herodias and Delilah. Yet she was included, with Judith and Esther, as one of [[Hans Burgkmair]]'s "Drei Gut Judin" ("Three Good Jewesses") trio of Biblical heroines in his ''Eighteen Worthies'', adding nine women to the traditional male [[Nine Worthies]].<ref>Russell, 29–39, No 1; Wolfthal, Diane (October 2000). Images of Rape: The Heroic Tradition and its Alternatives. Cambridge University Press. p. 123. {{ISBN|0521794420}}; Bohn, Babette (2005). The Artemisia Files "Death, Dispassion and the Female Hero:Gentileschi's Jael and Sisera". Chicago: University of Chicago Press. {{ISBN|0226035824}}.</ref>
[[File:Artemisia Gentileschi - Giuditta decapita Oloferne - Google Art Project-Adjust.jpg|thumb|left|260px|[[Artemisia Gentileschi]], ''[[Judith Slaying Holofernes (Artemisia Gentileschi)|Judith killing Holofernes]]'', version in Florence, 1621]]
The Power of Women subjects are seen in painting and other media, but [[old master print|prints]] were their special home. [[Lucas van Leyden]] made two sets of [[woodcut]]s known as ''[[Lucas van Leyden|The Large and Small Power of Women]]''. The subjects featured include [[Adam and Eve]], Samson and Delilah, King Solomon, [[Herod the Great|Herod]] and Herodias, Jael and Sisera, and, less usually, [[Jezebel]] and [[Ahab|King Ahab]]. The woodcuts have somewhat static compositions, and it has been suggested that they draw from [[tableaux vivants]] of the scenes.<ref>Russell, pp. 119, 153, Large: Nos 90, 96, 100; Small: Nos 66, 92; Snyder, 461-462. The small set, of 1516–19 included the scenes with Eve, Jael, Delilah, Solomon, Jezebel and Herodias, the large set of c. 1512 added Virgil and the legend of the ''[[Bocca della Verità]]'' or "Mouth of Truth" in Rome. The ''Aristotle and Phyllis'' of c. 1515 is in the same format but may be a later addition. Since no museum has a full set on the same paper they may have been sold mainly singly.</ref> Another set by [[Hans Burgkmair]] (1519) is known as the ''Liebestorheiten'' or ''Follies of Love''.<ref>Russell, p. 160, Nos 94, 97. This set contains: ''Samson and Delilah'', Bathsheba and David, The Idolatry of Solomon, and Phyllis riding Aristotle.</ref> At the same time there was also an interest, often among the same artists, in women from similar settings who were powerless, or only able to escape their situations by suicide, such as [[Susanna (Book of Daniel)|Susanna]], [[Dido of Carthage]], [[Lucretia]], and [[Verginia]].<ref>Russell, Nos 1–14</ref> The story of [[Esther]] lay somewhere between these two extremes.<ref>Russell, Nos 1, 15, 16</ref>
The [[Little Masters]] were among those artists greatly interested in both groups. The treatment of both groups, especially in prints, was often frankly erotic, and these groups took their place alongside female saints and lovers both mythological and realistic in the common treatments of women in art. Interest in such themes spread to Italy, affecting [[Venice]] first, and the subjects became common in Late Renaissance Italian painting, and even more so during the Baroque, perhaps culminating in the work of [[Artemisia Gentileschi]], who painted nearly all the biblical Power of Women subjects, most more than once. While her choice of subjects is assumed to be driven by her difficult life, [[Cristofano Allori]]'s best known work, ''Judith with the Head of Holofernes'', uses as models his former mistress for [[Book of Judith|Judith]], with her mother as the maid, and a self-portrait for the head of [[Holofernes]].<ref>Lucy Whitaker, Martin Clayton, ''The Art of Italy in the Royal Collection; Renaissance and Baroque'', p.270, Royal Collection Publications, 2007, {{ISBN|9781902163291}}</ref>
In Northern painting, the Cranachs were the first artists to paint the subjects often.<ref>Ainsworth, p. 66</ref> In 1513 [[Lucas Cranach the Elder]] decorated the nuptial bed of [[John, Elector of Saxony]] with a set of scenes including ''The Idolatry of Solomon'' as well as ''[[Hercules]] and [[Omphale]]'' (see below) and the ''[[Judgement of Paris]]''. The respective sons of the patron and artist, [[John Frederick I, Elector of Saxony]] and [[Lucas Cranach the Younger]], generated another set of paintings, now in the [[Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister]].<ref>Ainsworth, p. 62</ref> The possibility has been raised that some of the Cranach workshop's many ''Judith''s are portraits of ladies at the Saxon court;<ref>Ainsworth, pp. 63–66</ref> some other paintings of Jael certainly are portraits.
===Themes and context=== [[File:Lucas van Leyden Arisztotelész és Phyllis.jpg|thumb|left|''Phyllis Riding Aristotle'', [[Lucas van Leyden]]]] Several of these subjects contain a part-comical element of [[role reversal]] in a society that was essentially patriarchal, above all the "quintessential image from the Power of Women topos, ''Phyllis Riding Aristotle''."<ref>Russell, p. 175</ref> The story of Phyllis and Aristotle dates from the early 13th century (when the ''Lai d'Aristote'' was written) and became the subject of popular poems, plays and moralizing sermons.<ref>Boitani & Torti p. 82</ref> The theme was first analysed by [[Natalie Zemon Davis]] in 1975,<ref>"Women on Top" in her ''Society and Culture in Early Modern France: Eight Essays, Stanford, California: Stanford University Press, 1975''</ref> who concluded that the "overall functions" of these reversals was that "they afforded an expression of, and an outlet for, conflicts about authority within the system; and they also provided occasions by which the authoritarian current in family, workshop, and political life could be moderated by the laughter of disorder and paradoxical play. Accordingly they served to reinforce hierarchical structure".<ref>Natalie Zemon Davis, "Women on Top", quoted by Russell, p. 175</ref> The role reversal subject of [[Hercules]] and [[Omphale]] did not fit the main Power of Women trope, as Hercules' period serving Omphale was not caused by interaction between them, and they later married. It became popular from the 16th century, and the Cranach family painted many versions showing Omphale and her ladies dressing Hercules in drag.<ref>For a long analysis of the theme, see Rosenthal, Lisa, "Hercules' Distaff", especially p. 128 ff, in ''Gender, Politics, and Allegory in the Art of Rubens'', 2005, Cambridge University Press, {{ISBN|0521842441}}, 9780521842440, [https://books.google.com/books?id=tIa0iUVpGbcC&pg=PA128 Google Books]</ref>
''Phyllis Riding Aristotle'' was painted on the walls of several German [[town hall]]s,<ref>Russell, p. 150; Parshall, pp. 234-235</ref> though the design [[Albrecht Dürer]] made for [[Nuremberg]], as part of a Power of Women cycle, was never carried out.<ref>Foister p. 2</ref> Some sets of prints have ornamental borders that suggest they were intended to be pasted to walls, as many larger prints were. While many of the smaller prints were probably mostly seen by male collectors and their friends, these paintings and wall-mounted prints "must have been intended to entertain or amuse both men and women".<ref>Russell, p. 150; Parshall, pp. 234–235. Dürer's [[watercolour]] design is in the [[Morgan Library]] ([[:File:Albrecht Dürer - Design for Decoration of the Town Hall of Nuremberg.jpg|see Commons image]]), and has roundels with Bathsheba and David, [[Samson and Delilah (disambiguation)|Samson and Delilah]], and Phyllis riding Aristotle.</ref> Some of the Florentine [[Otto prints]], essentially designed for a female audience, show women triumphing over men, though most show pacific scenes of lovers.<ref>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=756921&partId=1 example, British Museum]. This collection, in the [[British Museum]] is the pattern book of a workshop probably making inserts for small boxes of sweet delicacies such as were given to the guests at weddings.</ref>
Other large prints intended for walls, where Power of Women subjects are especially common, adopt a different type of composition from the small prints with a few figures, showing large and well-populated panoramic scenes where the key figures can be hard to pick out. ''David and Bathsheba'' or Salome's story are set amid wide townscapes, and Judith kills Holofernes in a corner of a huge battle scene in front of a walled city.<ref>Bartrum, p. 154, Nos. 96, 158, 160; Parshall, pp. 234-235</ref>
The association of witchcraft specifically and almost exclusively with women was a novelty of the late 15th century, for which the book ''[[Malleus Maleficarum]]'' (1486) remains an emblem, though its significance has been questioned. The interpretation of the many images of witches has been the subject of considerable scholarly interest in recent decades, and many differing interpretations have been put forward. As well as allowing scope for imaginative fantasy, an erotic element is clear, above all in the work of [[Hans Baldung Grien]], the artist most associated with the subject. The seriousness with which either the artist or their audience took the reality of witchcraft has been questioned; to some extent these seem to have been the [[horror movie]]s of their day.<ref>Zika, Charles, "Images of Witchcraft in Early Modern Europe", in Levack, Brian P. (ed), ''The Oxford Handbook of Witchcraft in Early Modern Europe and Colonial America'', 2013, Oxford University Press, {{ISBN|0199578168}}, 9780199578160, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Lum96_FPZp0C&pg=PA143 Google Books]; Russell, pp. 14, 147–148, Nos 103–105; Harbison, Craig. ''The Art of the Northern Renaissance'', pp. 120–121, 1995, Weidenfeld & Nicolson, {{ISBN|0297835122}}; Bartrum, 69–70; there is a further account of the development of scholarship by Zika in [https://books.google.com/books?id=SRvhAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA48 pp. 48–65 here]</ref> The [[Witch of Endor]] was a previously obscure subject that allowed the combination of biblical and witchcraft interest.
==Gallery== <gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="4"> File:French - Writing Tablet with Scenes from the Lives of Virgil and Aristotle - Walters 71267.jpg|French Gothic ivory writing tablet cover with Phyllis seducing [[Aristotle]] and [[Virgil]] in his basket, 1340–60 File:Siege castle love Louvre OA6933.jpg|''[[Assault on the Castle of Love]]'', ivory mirror case, 1340–60, France File:Master Of The Housebook - Aristotle and Phyllis - WGA14556.jpg|[[Master of the Housebook]], ''Aristotle and Phyllis'', 15th-century [[engraving]] File:Lucas Cranach d.Ä. - Phyllis und Aristotle (1530).jpg|''Phyllis and Aristotle'' by Lucas Cranach the Elder, 1530 File:Delila schert Simson die Haare.jpg|[[Master E.S.]], Samson and Delilah, 1460s File:Israel van Meckenem - Das böse Weib.jpg|The "Battle for the Trousers" motif: [[Israhel van Meckenem]], ''The Angry Wife'', genre engraving, 1490s<ref>Russell, No. 125</ref> File:90Israhel van Meckenenem Verkehrte Welt.jpg|Another van Meckenem; here the man performs the normally female work of [[Hand spinning|spinning]] while his partner threatens him with an elaborate object suggesting power. File:Juan de Flandes - Herodias' Revenge - WGA12038.jpg|[[Juan de Flandes]], ''[[Herodias]]' Revenge'', 1496 File:Walcourt - Miséricorde - Tournoi de femmes.JPG|Early 16th-century [[misericord]] of two women jousting, mounted on men, [[Walcourt]], Belgium File:Lucas van Leyden 061.jpg|[[Lucas van Leyden]], ''The Idolatry of [[Solomon]]'', inspired by his pagan wife, from the "Large Power of Women" set of woodcuts, 1514<ref>Russell, No. 100</ref> File:Bewitched Stable Groom by Hans Baldung Grien.jpg|''Bewitched Stable Groom'', [[Hans Baldung Grien]], c. 1534<ref>Russell, No. 105</ref> File:Judith with the Head of Holofernes.jpg|[[Sebald Beham]], ''Judith with the Head of Holofernes'', 1547<ref>Russell, No. 28</ref>
</gallery>
==See also== {{Commons category|Power of Women}} *[[Timoclea]] *[[Master of the Weibermacht]]
==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}}
==References== *Ainsworth, Maryan Wynn, et al., ''German Paintings in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1350-1600'', 2013, Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York, N.Y.), {{ISBN|1588394875}}, 9781588394873, [https://books.google.com/books?id=MKkSBtJNBUwC&pg=PA59 google books] *Bartrum,Giulia; German Renaissance Prints, 1490–1550; British Museum Press, 1995, {{ISBN|978-0-7141-2604-3}} *{{cite book|last1=Boitani|first1=Piero|last2=Torti|first2=Anna|title=The Body and the Soul in Medieval Literature|date=1999|publisher=Boydell & Brewer|isbn=9780859915458|url={{Google books|mckhSghfWM4C|The Body and the Soul in Medieval Literature|page=82|plainurl= yes}}}} *{{cite web|last1=Foister|first1=Susan|title=Dürer's Nuremberg Legacy|url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/pdf/2%20Durer%20Nuremberg%20Legacy.pdf|publisher=British Museum}} *Hall, James, ''Hall's Dictionary of Subjects and Symbols in Art'', 1996 (2nd edn.), John Murray, {{ISBN|0719541476}} *{{cite journal|last=Harp|first=Margaret|year=1996|title=Rev. of Smith, ''The Power of Women''|journal=[[Rocky Mountain Review of Language and Literature]]|volume=50|issue=2|pages=208–10|jstor=1348248}} * {{cite journal|last1=Nurse|first1=Julia|title=She-Devils, Harlots and Harridans in Northern Renaissance Prints|journal=History Today|date=July 1998|volume=48|issue=7}} *Parshall, Peter, in Landau, David, and Parshall, Peter. ''The Renaissance Print'', Yale, 1996, {{ISBN|0300068832}} *Russell, H Diane (ed), ''Eva/Ave; Women in Renaissance and Baroque Prints'', National Gallery of Art, Washington, 1990, {{ISBN|1558610391}} * {{cite book|last1=Salomon|first1=Nanette|title=Shifting Priorities: Gender and Genre in Seventeenth-Century Dutch Painting|date=2004|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=978-0804744775|url={{Google books|t90DUibNUMoC|Shifting Priorities: Gender and Genre in Seventeenth-Century Dutch Painting|plainurl= yes}}}} *[[James Snyder (art historian)|Snyder, James]]. ''Northern Renaissance Art'', 1985, Harry N. Abrams, {{ISBN|0136235964}} * Wolfthal, Diane. "Susan L. Smith, The Power of Women: A Topos in Medieval Art and Literature. University of Pennsylvania Press, 1995" Medieval Feminist Newsletter 22 (1996)
==Further reading== *Smith, Susan L., ''The Power of Women: A 'Topos' in Medieval Art and Literature.'', University of Pennsylvania Press, 1995, {{ISBN|978-0-8122-3279-0}} *Tal, Guy, ''Witches on Top: Magic, Power, and Imagination in the Art of Early Modern Italy'', Dissertation, Indiana University, 2006, Proquest, {{ISBN|0542847914}}, 9780542847912
